title: South Carolina Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House
description: Interprets S.C. Code Ann. Section 42-1-415(A) and (B) to allow a higher-tier contractor to obtain reimbursement from the Uninsured Employer's Fund for benefits paid to a subcontractor's injured employee upon a showing the higher-tier contractor obtained evidence of workers' compensation coverage at the time the subcontractor was originally engaged to perform the work.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Roy R. House, Claimant,
        andÂ  Jack Clark and Vaughn Homes, Inc. and/or Jack Clark Constructions 
          and Travelers/Zurich, Defendants,
        of whom Roy R. House is Respondent.
        and Vaughn Homes, Inc. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3850
  Heard April 8, 2004 â€“ Filed August 2, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant. 
        Edgar W. Dickson, of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation 
  case, Vaughn Homes, Inc. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the full 
  commission and concluding Vaughn was liable for injuries sustained by an employee 
  of its subcontractor.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Vaughn Homes, a housing contractor, subcontracted with Jack Clark Constructions 
  for framing work.Â  Roy House, an employee of Clark, filed a workersâ€™ compensation 
  claim after he was injured in the course and scope of his employment with Clark.Â  
  At the time of Houseâ€™s accident, Clark did not have workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  

When he was initially engaged to perform the work, Clark presented Vaughn with 
  a certificate indicating he had workersâ€™ compensation coverage from June 5, 
  1997, to June 5, 1998.Â  Upon the expiration of the original term, Clark provided 
  a certificate indicating continued coverage until June 7, 1999.Â  The history 
  of the policy indicates several instances of cancellation and reinstatement, 
  all based on nonpayment of premiums, until, in March 1999, Clark received notification 
  from his agent that the policy was due to expire in June.Â  A notice of cancellation 
  was served on Clark prior to the date of expiration, but Clark failed to pay 
  the renewal premium.Â  
Clark applied for a new policy with another insurance 
  agency on July 1, 1999, but coverage was declined.Â  Clark continued to perform 
  work for Vaughn, but admitted he neither notified Vaughn that his coverage had 
  lapsed for nonpayment nor advised Vaughn that his application for other coverage 
  was declined.Â  Clark, however, continued to verbally advise Vaughn that he did 
  have coverage.Â  
Following hearings on Houseâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim, the single commissioner 
  transferred Vaughnâ€™s liability to the South Carolina Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund, 
  concluding Clark committed fraud by failing to notify its higher-tier contractor 
  of a lapse in coverage pursuant to South Carolina Code section 42-1-415(C) (Supp. 
  2003).Â  The full commission affirmed but the circuit court reversed, finding 
  Vaughn had notice of the expiration of Clarkâ€™s policy and failed to require 
  proof of coverage after the policy expired.Â  
SCOPE OF REVIEW
 When reviewing an appeal from the workersâ€™ compensation commission, the circuit 
  and appellate courts are proscribed from weighing the evidence or substituting 
  their judgment for that of the full commission on questions of fact.Â  However, 
  the reviewing court may reverse when a decision is predicated on an error of 
  law.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 353 S.C. 339, 344-45, 577 S.E.2d 
  475, 477-78 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d as modified, 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 
  272 (2004).Â  Statutory interpretation is a question of law.Â  Stewart v. Richland 
  Memâ€™l Hosp., 350 S.C. 589, 593, 567 S.E.2d 510, 512 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Vaughn argues it may transfer liability for Houseâ€™s injuries to the fund pursuant 
  to South Carolina Code Ann. section 42-1-415 (Supp. 2003).Â  Vaughn contends 
  the circuit court erred by interpreting section 42-1-415 to require a higher-tier 
  contractor to continue to collect proof of insurance coverage from its subcontractor 
  after originally collecting documentation at the time of hire.Â  We agree.Â  
The full commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s decision to relieve 
  Vaughn of liability based on the finding Clark committed fraud pursuant to section 
  42-1-415(C) (Supp. 2003).Â  In reversing, the circuit court concluded Vaughn 
  had notice that Clarkâ€™s policy would expire, and reasoned the burden fell upon 
  Vaughn to require appropriate evidence of continued coverage.Â  The court further 
  determined the commission erred as a matter of law in finding Clark committed 
  fraud, based essentially on two premises.Â  The first premise was that Clark 
  never represented to Vaughn that he had insurance coverage for any period of 
  time subsequent to June 7, 1999, and therefore could not be guilty of fraudulently 
  representing that he did.Â  As a second premise, the circuit court concluded 
  the expiration of a policy at the end of its term was not the type of â€œlapseâ€ 
  contemplated by the provisions of section 42-1-415.Â  
However, neither the commissionâ€™s finding of fraud nor the circuit courtâ€™s 
  focus on notice is determinative of whether liability may be transferred under 
  section 42-1-415.Â  Under subsection 42-1-415(A), a statutory employer, such 
  as Vaughn, may transfer liability to the fund when a subcontractorâ€™s employee 
  is injured if the statutory employer submits documentation to the fund that 
  the subcontractor has represented himself as having workersâ€™ compensation coverage 
  â€œat the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 42-1-415(A) (Supp. 2003); see also Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, 
  Ltd., 337 S.C. 313, 330, 523 S.E.2d 766, 774-75 (1999) (noting that pursuant 
  to section Â§ 42-1-415(A), â€œa statutory employer is no longer directly liable 
  for workersâ€™ compensation payments whenever documentation is presented to the 
  commission that a contractor or subcontractor represented himself to the statutory 
  employer as having workersâ€™ compensation insuranceâ€).Â  Subsection (B) permits 
  a higher-tier contractor to qualify for reimbursement of benefits paid if it 
  collects documentation of insurance coverage â€œat the time the . . . subcontractor 
  is engaged to perform work.â€Â  S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (B).Â  
 When the language of a statute is plain, unambiguous and conveys a clear and 
  definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are unnecessary and 
  the court may not impose another meaning.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 
  79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  Under these circumstances, the court will 
  not resort to subtle or forced construction in an attempt to limit or expand 
  a statuteâ€™s scope.Â  Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436-37, 
  454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995).Â  
Subsections (A) and (B) of section 42-1-415 set out the procedure the higher-tier 
  contractor must follow in order to relieve itself of responsibility for workplace 
  injuries to the employees of its subcontractors.Â  Vaughn complied fully with 
  the mandate of subsections (A) and (B) when it collected documentation of insurance 
  at the time Clark â€œwas engaged to perform work.â€Â  The statute does not require 
  a prime contractor to continue collecting proof of its subcontractorâ€™s insurance 
  coverage after the subcontractor is engaged to perform the work.Â  We are loath 
  to read such a requirement into a statute that otherwise contains such straightforward 
  language.Â  
Subsection (C) of section 42-1-415 is directed toward the subcontractor, places 
  upon it the duty to notify the higher-tier contractor of any lapse in coverage, 
  and sets forth the consequences of the subcontractorâ€™s failure to do so when 
  it provides, in relevant part:
 
  Knowing and wilful failure to notify, by certified mail, the higher tier 
    . . . contractor . . . who originally was provided documentation of workersâ€™ 
    compensation coverage of a lapse in coverage within five days after the lapse 
    is considered fraud and subjects the . . . subcontractor who represented himself 
    as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance to the penalties for fraud provided 
    by law. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415(C).Â  
The use in subsection (C) of the word â€œoriginallyâ€ lends support to the reasoning 
  that the information given at the inception of the engagement is the controlling 
  factor, negating any statutory requirement on the part of the higher-tier contractor 
  to continue collecting proof of insurance.Â  

  Statutes which are part of the same legislative scheme should be construed 
    together.Â  In construing statutory language, the statute must be read as a 
    whole, and sections which are part of the same general statutory law must 
    be construed together and each one given effect, if it can be done by any 
    reasonable construction.Â  

State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 152, 588 S.E.2d 
  105, 110 (2003) (internal citation omitted). 
We hold that because Vaughn complied with the provisions of section 42-1-415(A) 
  and (B), it is entitled to shift the burden of paying workersâ€™ compensation 
  benefits to the fund.Â  The order of the circuit court is, therefore,
REVERSED.Â  
HUFF, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â

title: Shapemasters Golf Course Builders, Inc. v. Shapemasters, Inc.
description: Appellants appeal various aspects of the trial court's ruling in favor of Respondents in this shareholder derivative action.  The Court of Appeals affirmed part of the the trial court's ruling, dismissed the appeal and and remanded the matter for further proceediings.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Shapemasters Golf Course Builders, Inc., James Michael Harbin, Joseph 
          Cagle and Benton Marc Burger, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Shapemasters, Inc., Jeffrey Stein and Lilly Jayawant a/k/a Lilly Stein, 
          Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3851
  Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed August 2, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; DISMISSED IN PART;
  AND REMANDED

 
   
     
       
        
          Adam Fisher, Jr., of Greenville; Charles Craig Young, of Florence; 
            and Jonathan P. Kresken, of North Myrtle Beach, for Appellants.
          Michael R. Daniel and M. Anthony Stith, Jr., both of Mt. Pleasant, 
            for Respondents.
        
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Shapemasters, Inc., 
  Jeffrey Stein and Lilly Jayawant, a/k/a Lilly Stein (â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal various 
  aspects of the trial courtâ€™s order in favor of Shapemasters Golf Course Builders, 
  Inc., James Michael Harbin, Joseph Cagle, and Benton Burger (â€œRespondentsâ€), 
  in this shareholder derivative action.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1993, Respondents James Harbin and Joseph Cagle, together with Appellant 
  Jeffrey Stein, established Shapemasters, Inc. (â€œS.C. Corp.â€), a South Carolina 
  corporation engaged in the business of golf course construction.Â  In 2001, the 
  same parties established Shapemasters Golf Course Builders, Inc. (â€œN.C. Corp.â€), 
  a North Carolina corporation for the same purpose. 
Respondents Cagle and Harbin ceased active involvement in S.C. Corp., and only 
  remained associated with the company as shareholders.Â  At that point, Appellant 
  Jeffrey Stein operated S.C. Corp. and Respondents Harbin, Cagle, and Burger 
  operated N.C. Corp.Â  Appellants claim Stein, Harbin, and Cagle own S.C. Corp., 
  and Harbin, Cagle, Burger, and Stein own N.C. Corp. 
  [1]  
In December 2001, Respondents commenced this action against Appellants asserting 
  several causes of action.Â  Appellants answered and counterclaimed seeking, in 
  part, an accounting, stock buy out, and a temporary restraining order.Â  
Both parties filed motions for the appointment of a custodian to protect the 
  assets of the various companies while the case was being litigated.Â  Respondents 
  agreed to the appointment of a custodian for N.C. Corp., but Appellants objected 
  to a custodian being appointed for S.C. Corp. on grounds that such an appointment 
  would be unduly costly and burdensome.Â  
The trial court found that Respondents successfully made a prima facie case 
  to justify the appointment of a custodian to oversee S.C. Corp.Â  The court granted 
  Respondentsâ€™ request for an appointment in an order dated July 15, 2002.Â  The 
  courtâ€™s order delineated the responsibility of the custodian, including that 
  he or she should assemble and review both of the companiesâ€™ financial statements, 
  seek to maximize profits, and serve bi-monthly income and expenditure reports 
  on attorneys for each party.Â  
Appellants filed a motion to alter or amend the July 15, 2002 order. In addition, 
  Appellants filed supplemental motions seeking the withdrawal of the courtâ€™s 
  July 15, 2002 order, referral to a master-in-equity, the termination of discovery, 
  elimination of a custodian for S.C. Corp., restraining orders preventing anyone 
  from competing with the two companies or obtaining employment with a competitor, 
  restraining order preventing Respondents from using the name or logo â€œShapemastersâ€ 
  in their business dealings, eliminating any commingling of assets between the 
  two companies, and the designation of a CPA to audit the companies.Â  
In response to these motions the trial court issued a second order dated December 
  21, 2002.Â  This order vacated the courtâ€™s July 15, 2002 order.Â  The court ordered 
  mediation and referred the case to a master-in-equity with the reservation that 
  the master should report any jury matters.Â  The court also ordered an audit 
  going back to 1996, denied Appellantsâ€™ request to eliminate the need for a custodian, 
  appointed Richard E. Heath as the custodian, denied Appellantsâ€™ request to end 
  discovery, and denied Appellantsâ€™ requests that Respondents be restrained from 
  working for competitors. As to the use of the name and logo â€œShapemasters,â€ 
  the trial court specifically reserved ruling on the issue, stating that the 
  master should address it in his final order.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUES 
  [2] 

   
    I.
    
    Is the denial of a restraining order immediately appealable? 
      
    
  
   
    II. 
    
    Did the trial court err in refusing to grant Appellantsâ€™ 
      motion for a restraining order?
    
  
   
    III. 
    
    Is the appointment of a custodian immediately appealable? 
      
    
  
  
    IV. 
    
     
      Did the trial court err in appointing a custodian to oversee 
        operations? 
      
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
 I. Restraining Order
Appellants first assert the trial court erred in refusing to grant Appellantsâ€™ 
  motion for a restraining order with regards to the use of the â€œShapemastersâ€ 
  name and logo and regarding Cagleâ€™s, a Respondent in this matter, employment 
  with a direct competitor.Â  We disagree.Â  
Appellants correctly argue that the refusal to 
  grant a restraining order is immediately appealable.Â  â€œAn order or decree in 
  a court of common pleas granting, continuing, modifying, or refusing an injunction 
  is immediately appealable.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§ 14-3-330(4); see also 
  Appeal of Paslay, 230 S.C. 55, 64, 94 S.E.2d 57, 61 (1956) (appeal lay 
  from the restraining order or temporary injunction). However, we must first 
  determine whether the issue is preserved for appellate review.
Appellants further argue the trial court erred 
  in refusing to grant an injunction regarding the use of the name Shapemasters 
  as the company logo and name.Â  Appellants argue that Cagle and other Respondents 
  in this matter are not only using the company name, but also working with a 
  direct competitor. 
The trial judge did not rule on the use of the 
  Shapemasters name and logo issue. Further, Appellants failed to pursue a Rule 
  59 motion on the December 2002 order; therefore, the issue is not preserved 
  for review. [3] Â  Moreover, we believe Appellantsâ€™ arguments 
  are without merit.Â  Appellants consented to the use of the name and logo when 
  they established N.C. Corp.Â  N.C. Corp. has been conducting business under the 
  Shapemasters name since its formation in 2001.Â  To require N.C. Corp to cease 
  the use of the name and logo during the pendency of this action would disrupt 
  business and have an unduly negative impact on N.C. Corp. Appellants and Respondents 
  are shareholders in N.C. Corp. and will share any profits generated by N.C. 
  Corp.Â  
Additionally, Appellants have failed to show irreparable 
  harm with regards to Appellantsâ€™ employees working for competitors.Â  See 
  FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 352 S.C. 408, 416, 574 S.E.2d 
  228, 232 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œGenerally, to obtain an injunction, a party must 
  demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and an 
  inadequate remedy at law.â€). The fact that Appellantsâ€™ employees occasionally 
  work for direct competitors is not unduly harmful to Appellants as there is 
  no evidence in the record that the employees acquired, or attempted to acquire, 
  any business for the competitor.Â  In fact, the record reflects that the employeesâ€™ 
  function for competitors is one of providing labor as heavy machine operators.Â  
  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling.
 II.  Appointment of Custodian
Appellants next assert that the appointment of 
  a custodian is immediately appealable and that the trial court erred in appointing 
  a custodian to manage the daily operations of the companyâ€™s affairs.Â  Appellants 
  assert that the appointment of a custodian has the same effect as the appointment 
  of a receiver.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(4) (stating an appellate 
  court has jurisdiction to review an interlocutory order refusing the appointment 
  of a receiver).Â  We disagree.
Receivers and custodians are distinguishable.Â  
  A receiverâ€™s duty is to wind up and liquidate the business and affairs of a 
  corporation, while custodians manage the affairs of the corporation.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. 33-14-320 (Supp. 2003).Â  A receiver, in performing its duties, 
  may:

  [D]ispose of all or any part of the assets of the corporation wherever located, 
    at a public or private sale, if authorized by the court; and (ii) may sue 
    and defend in his own name as receiver of the corporation in all courts of 
    this State.

However, a custodian may:

  [E]xercise all of the powers of the corporation, through or in place of its 
    board of directors or officers, to the extent necessary to manage the affairs 
    of the corporation in the best interests of its shareholders and creditors.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-320(c)(2).
â€œOne of the purposes of a receivership is that the 
  assets shall be held in impartial hands, that the proceeds may be administered 
  according to the priorities of the claims thereto.â€Â  National Cash Register 
  Co. v. Burns, 217 S.C. 310, 316, 60 S.E.2d 615, 618 (1950). The refusal 
  of a trial court to appoint a receiver should be immediately appealable because 
  of the potential harm in not having an unbiased party to protect a corporationâ€™s 
  assets.Â  We do not believe the same level of harm attends an order to appoint 
  a custodian.Â  The custodian in this matter was appointed specifically for the 
  purposes of â€œoverseeing ongoing projects and to allocate man and machinery among 
  the proposed projects to maximize profits.â€Â  The trial court did not commit 
  error in appointing a custodian and assigning him with the aforementioned duties.Â  
  Additionally, we do not believe the term receiver, as set forth in section 14-3-320(4) 
  has the same effect as the term custodian.Â  Therefore the courtâ€™s order to appoint 
  a custodian is interlocutory and not immediately appealable.  [4] 
CONCLUSION
The lower court did not err in refusing to grant a restraining order regarding 
  the use of the Shapemastersâ€™ name and logo.Â  Further, the appointment of a custodian 
  is interlocutory in nature and does not fall into a delineated exception. Â As 
  such, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED IN PART; DISMISSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.


 
   
    [1] Respondents aver that prior to the establishment of N.C. Corp., Burger 
    became a 25% shareholder in S.C. Corp.Â  Accordingly, Respondents assert the 
    four partners own equal 25% interests in both companies.Â  

 
   
    [2] Appellants state a total of seven issues on appeal. However, we feel 
    that most of the issues may be condensed into four issues for our consideration. 
    Appellantsâ€™ remaining issues are unsupported by authority and are deemed abandoned.

 
   [3]  See I'On v. Town of 
    Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (stating parties should 
    raise all necessary issues and arguments to trial court and attempt to obtain 
    a ruling); Townsend v. City of Dillon, 326 S.C. 244, 486 S.E.2d 95 
    (1997) (holding issues not ruled upon by the trial judge are not preserved 
    for appellate review); Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 
    122 (1991) (ruling issue was not preserved for appellate review where the 
    trial court did not explicitly rule on the appellant's argument and the appellant 
    made no Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment). 

 
   
    [4] It is not necessary for this court to address Appellantsâ€™ remaining 
    issues because Appellants fail to provide legal authority to support their 
    arguments.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 
    444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (holding when a party fails to provide arguments 
    or supporting authority for his assertion, the party is deemed to have abandoned 
    the issue).Â  Moreover, Appellantâ€™s remaining issues are without merit.

title: Holroyd v. Requa
description: This is an appeal from a malpractice action brought by an insured/employee and employer against the insurance agent who marketed the company's health insurance plan.  The agent appeals the jury's verdict for the employee and employer, arguing that:  (1) the claims were preempted by ERISA; (2) the trial judge erred in admitting certain evidence and testimony; (3) the trial judge erred in failing to grant the agent a new trial; and (4) the trial judge erred in failing to grant the agent's motion for a change of venue.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Christopher Holroyd, Gillian Holroyd and American AVK Co.,
        Respondents,
v.
Michael R. Requa, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3852
Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed August 
  9, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Eugene N. Zeigler, Hamilton Osborne, Jr. and James Y. Becker, 
  all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Justin Oâ€™Toole Lucey and Mary L. Arnold, both of Mt. Pleasant, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Christopher 
  Holroyd, Gillian Holroyd, and American AVK Company (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€) 
  brought this action against their insurance agent, Michael Requa, alleging various 
  causes of action for misrepresentation, fraud, and negligence stemming from 
  Requaâ€™s solicitation and sale of a health insurance policy to Respondents.Â  
  Requa denied these allegations and claimed Respondentsâ€™ state law causes of 
  action were preempted and barred by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security 
  Act, 29 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1001 to -1461 (Supp. 2003) (â€œERISAâ€).Â  The jury rendered a 
  verdict in favor of Respondents.Â  The trial court subsequently denied Requaâ€™s 
  post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and new trial.Â  
  Requa now appeals.Â  We affirm.
BACKGROUND
Requa was an insurance agent doing business 
  in Moncks Corner, South Carolina.Â  At the center of this case is a health insurance 
  plan administered by Fidelity Group, Inc., that Requa marketed to American AVK 
  Company for its employees.Â  At issue was whether Requa was liable for Fidelityâ€™s 
  failure to pay legitimate medical expense claims filed by Holroyd, one of American 
  AVKâ€™s employees.
Fidelityâ€™s Health Insurance Plan
The program administered by Fidelity was 
  not a typical insurance plan.Â  Rather than being developed and sold by a traditional 
  insurance company, the Fidelity plan was the product of an association of several 
  distinct entities.Â  
Around 1995, a purported employee union 
  called the International Workers Guild (IWG) (also known as the International 
  Workers Association) entered into a collective bargaining agreement with a purported 
  employerâ€™s association, the National Association of Business Owners and Professionals 
  (NABOP). [1] Â  Under this agreement, 
  employees joining IWG would be provided healthcare benefits through a third-party-trust 
  called the International Guild Health and Welfare Trust Fund (IWG Fund).Â  The 
  arrangement provided in part that employers would join the collectively bargained 
  agreement prepared by the organizers of the arrangement with IWG and NABOP.Â  
  Employees paid membership dues to IWG, and the employers made monthly contributions 
  on behalf of their enrolled employees.Â  The IWG Fund managed the plan, and Fidelity 
  marketed it and administered claims. 
Requa was recruited to market the 
  Fidelity plan to his customers by John Branham and Marty Geitler, the exclusive 
  general agents for the Plan.Â  Over the course of two meetings, Branham and Geitler 
  explained the structure and benefits of the Plan and provided Requa with marketing 
  materials prepared by Fidelity.Â  Several months later, Requa executed a marketing 
  agreement to act as agent for the Fidelity Plan. 
Requaâ€™s Solicitation of American 
  AVK
In late 1996, Requa sent a letter to American AVK 
  Company, a subsidiary of an international company with offices in California 
  and South Carolina, soliciting interest in a group health insurance program 
  from Fidelity Group, Inc. 
The letter described the pricing, benefits, and 
  network of care providers that were included in the Fidelity plan.Â  Requa made 
  various claims in the letter about the quality of the Fidelity plan.Â  He wrote 
  that it offered â€œgreat benefits with reasonable prices,â€ had â€œ[a] history of 
  low rate increases and an A+ rate,â€ was â€œ#1 in benefits compared to other carriers,â€ 
  and was â€œ[l]ocally strong with reciprocal access nationwide.â€Â  In addition to 
  these more subjective claims, Requa specifically noted that â€œ[t]he Fidelity 
  Group has an average annual rate increase of only 3.4% over the last 8 years.â€Â  
  The letter further claimed Fidelity was reinsured through â€œReliance [Reinsurance 
  Company], rated A+ by A.M. Best.â€ [2] Â  The Fidelity plan was the only product promoted 
  in the letter.
Shortly after receiving Requaâ€™s letter, American 
  AVK decided to enroll in the Fidelity Plan.Â  American AVK paid monthly premiums 
  for the coverage and the participating employees made monthly contributions.
Failure of the Fidelity Plan
Within months of American AVKâ€™s enrollment 
  in the Plan, Fidelity began having problems paying claims in a timely manner.Â  
  No later than July 1997, Requa was aware Fidelity was experiencing problemsâ€”specifically 
  advising one of his clients that â€œ[t]he Fidelity Group has apparently experienced 
  rapid growthâ€”too soonâ€”without the capacity to handle it.â€ 
Also in July 1997, Requa received a letter 
  from the South Carolina Department of Insurance notifying him that the Fidelity 
  Groupâ€™s insurance plan and Requaâ€™s involvement in marketing that plan were the 
  subject of an investigation as to whether Fidelity had complied with state law 
  regulating the sale of insurance.Â  The letter instructed Requa to immediately 
  cease the marketing and sale of the Plan until the Department of Insurance was 
  able to make a final determination.

  334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 575 (1999).Â  
The Legislature has 
  provided life expectancy tables to be considered when it is necessary in civil 
  actions to determine the life expectancy of any person.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 19-1-150 (1985) (â€œWhen it is necessary, in any civil action or other 
  mode of litigation, to establish the life expectancy of any person from any 
  period in his life, whether he be living at the time or not, the table below 
  shall be received in all courts and by all persons having power to determine 
  litigation as evidence (along with other evidence as to his health, constitution 
  and habits) of the life expectancy of such person.â€). 
  [4] 
During the charge conference, 
  the parties debated whether the mortality tables should be charged to the jury.Â  
  Requa argued that under ERISA, Holroyd would have â€œcredible coverage that would 
  have extended to any future coverageâ€ such that future damages, and the mortality 
  tables, were not an issue.Â  Noting there was evidence in the record regarding 
  future damages in the form of increased premiums, the trial court decided to 
  give the charge concerning the mortality tables.Â  The jury was instructed as 
  follows:

Now, at this time, Mr. Holroyd 
  is 52 years of age.Â  We have in this state a statute that has been established 
  by way of actuarial study that states what oneâ€™s life expectancy should be at 
  a certain age.Â  This is allowed into evidence at a trial.Â  At this age, 52, 
  Mr. Holroyd, has a life expectancy of 23.7 years.Â  In determining how long one 
  would live, you may consider life expectancy.Â  You may also consider other evidence 
  in the case which bears on his health, age, physical condition, or any other 
  factors that you deem appropriate in determining whether or not you would â€“ 
  in determining how you would use that life expectancy.Â  
You would not use that life expectancy 
  at all unless you determined that Mr. Holroyd would have some damages in the 
  future.Â  That has nothing to do with what has happened, has only to do with 
  what may happen in the future.

Requa informed the trial court 
  that he had no objections to the instructions.Â  In his post-trial motions, however, 
  Requa argued that charging the mortality tables was error because any increase 
  in premiums was due to the heart attack, not Requaâ€™s actions and the future 
  damages were in contravention of federal law.Â  The trial court denied the motion, 
  finding there was evidence to support the charge and Requa failed to object 
  after the instruction was given.Â Â  
Even assuming Requa 
  properly preserved this argument for appellate review, we find no error with 
  the instruction.Â  There was evidence that Holroyd would suffer future damages 
  due to increased premiums.Â  The jury could properly consider the mortality tables 
  to determine the amount of future damages.Â  Because there was evidence to support 
  the charge, the trial court correctly instructed the jury with regard to the 
  mortality tables.Â  The trial court did not err in denying Requaâ€™s post-trial 
  motion with regard to this issue.Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Change of Venue
Requa next argues the trial court 
  erred by failing to grant his motion for change of venue.Â  We disagree.Â  â€œA 
  motion for a change of venue is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial 
  judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. 
  Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 67, 502 S.E.2d 63, 71 (1998).
This action was filed 
  in Charleston County in January 1999.Â  Requa did not assert the defense of improper 
  venue in his pleadings, and he did not file his motion for change of venue until 
  April 2000.Â  The matter did not ultimately come before the trial court for hearing 
  until February 2001, at which time the case had already been placed on the trial 
  roster and was subject to being called for trial at any time.Â  Moreover, there 
  is evidence that most of the discovery had been completed prior to the hearing.
Requa points out that 
  the right of a defendant to be tried in the county of his residence is a substantial 
  right and argues he did not waive that right.Â  A defense of improper venue may 
  be waived if not made by motion under Rule 12, SCRCP, or raised as an affirmative 
  defense in a responsive pleading.Â  Henley v. North Trident Regâ€™l Hosp., 
  275 S.C. 193, 195, 269 S.E.2d 328, 328 (1980) (holding that the right to be 
  tried in the county of oneâ€™s residence, â€œwhile it is a â€˜substantial and valuable 
  right,â€™ . . . relates only to the question of venue and can be waivedâ€).
In Henley, our 
  supreme court held that the defendantâ€™s failure to challenge venue until five 
  months after the complaint had been filed was unreasonable, and he had therefore 
  waived his right to be tried in the county of his residence.Â  We find the same 
  result is warranted in the present case where the delay continued for many more 
  months and was not pursued with the trial court until the case was nearing trial.
Accordingly, we find 
  the trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying Requaâ€™s motion for change 
  of venue.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Damages
Requa next argues the 
  trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for a new trial or, in the 
  alternative, a new trial nisi remittitur on the grounds the damages awarded 
  by the jury were grossly disproportionate to the evidence.Â  We disagree.
â€œWhen a party moves 
  for a new trial based on a challenge that the verdict is either excessive or 
  inadequate, the trial judge must distinguish between awards that are merely 
  unduly liberal or conservative and awards that are actuated by passion, caprice 
  or prejudice.â€Â  Allstate Ins. Co. v. Durham, 314 S.C. 529, 530, 431 S.E.2d 
  557, 558 (1993).Â  The trial court must set aside a verdict only when it is shockingly 
  disproportionate to the injuries suffered and thus indicates that passion, caprice, 
  prejudice, or other considerations not reflected by the evidence affected the 
  amount awarded.Â  Vinson, 324 S.C. at 404, 477 S.E.2d at 723.Â  In other 
  words, to warrant a new trial absolute, the verdict reached must be so â€œgrossly 
  excessiveâ€ as to clearly indicate the influence of an improper motive on the 
  jury.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 379-80, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993).Â  
  Although the decision to grant or deny a new trial absolute based on the excessiveness 
  of a verdict rests in the sound discretion of the trial court, an abuse of discretion 
  occurs if the trial courtâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence 
  or the conclusions reached are controlled by an error of law.Â  Krepps v. 
  Ausen, 324 S.C. 597, 607, 479 S.E.2d 290, 295 (Ct. App. 1996).
Requa first claims the 
  juryâ€™s award of $365,000 in actual damages is unsupported by the evidence because 
  Respondents only presented evidence of $65,000 in unpaid medical bills. Â The 
  evidence offered by Respondents not only included unpaid medical bills, but 
  also included embarrassment, humiliation, credit problems, increased future 
  insurance premiums, stress, premiums paid, and decreased coverage due to preexisting 
  conditions in a new policy.Â  We find no reason, therefore, to disturb the juryâ€™s 
  verdict.
With respect to punitive 
  damages, Requa argues the juryâ€™s award of $180,000 was clearly motivated by 
  passion, caprice, and prejudice.Â  Here, too, we see no reason to disturb the 
  trial courtâ€™s finding that the punitive damages award was supported by and not 
  disproportionate to the evidence.Â  The trial court separately listed and addressed 
  the eight factors required in a post-trial review of punitive damages awards 
  under our Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling in Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 
  406 S.E.2d 350 (1991).Â  Requaâ€™s culpability, knowledge, and ability to pay are 
  amply supported by the evidence contained in the record.Â  
In light of all the evidence 
  presented, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding the 
  actual and punitive damages were not disproportionate to the evidence.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated 
  above, we find: that the Respondentsâ€™ claims were not preempted by federal ERISA 
  laws; that the trial court correctly ruled on Requaâ€™s evidentiary objections; 
  that Requaâ€™s motion for a change of venue was correctly denied; and that the 
  trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying Requaâ€™s motions for new 
  trial.Â  The judgment of the trial court is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Testimony from Respondentsâ€™ witnesses indicated that the entities 
    were not true employer or employee organizations under ERISA.Â Â  However, the 
    trial court did not make specific findings in this regard, and it is not necessary 
    to our decision in this case.Â  

 
   
    [2]  A.M. Best Company rates insurance companies based on their financial 
    ability to meet their ongoing obligations.

 
   
    [3]  Â We also note that Requa admits in his brief that it was his burden 
    to prove the existence of a recognized ERISA plan before the trial court could 
    determine whether state law claims were preempted.Â  He also admits that the 
    fact of whether the Fidelity plan was an ERISA plan was â€œa question of fact 
    that has yet to be determined.â€Â  Requaâ€™s admitted failure to provide any evidence 
    at trial that the plan was an ERISA plan is an additional ground supporting 
    the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny his motions for directed verdict and JNOV.Â  
  

 
   [4]  This statute was amended in April 2004.Â  The amendment 
    has no effect on the issue in this case.Â

title: McClain v. Pactiv Corporation
description: This case affirms the trial court's ruling that the action for intentional infliction of emotional distress is exclusively within the jurisdiction of the Workers' Compensation Act, but reverses the holding that a federal court dismissal of a section 1983 action collaterally estops the claimant from asserting certain state law causes of action.
text:
McClain v. Pactiv


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gary E. McClain, Appellant,
v.
Pactiv Corporation, Howard Sellers, Tim Randall, Jody Rowland, Joseph 
        P. Berley, Linda Milton, Joe Powell, Doug Boynton, Larry Wonoski, Joe 
        Garrison, Ron Clark and Robin Montgomery, Defendants,
of whom Pactiv Corporation and Joseph P. Berley are,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3853
Heard 
  June 23, 2004 â€“ Filed August 9, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED.


  
    
      
J. Dennis Bolt, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Paul H. Derrick and Kristin E. 
  Toussaint, both 
  of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Gary E. McClain appeals the 
  dismissal of his causes of action against Pactiv Corporation and Joseph P. Berley.Â  
  He argues the trial court erred in (1) ruling his intentional infliction of 
  emotional distress claim was barred by the exclusivity provision of the South 
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and (2) concluding his remaining claimsâ€”civil 
  conspiracy, false arrest, abuse of legal process, and invasion of privacyâ€”were 
  barred by the doctrine of collateral estoppel.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in 
  part, and remand. 
BACKGROUND
This case arises from McClainâ€™s allegations 
  that his former employer, Pactiv, and fellow employees conspired with each other 
  and with law enforcement to have him arrested and involuntarily committed after 
  he spoke in favor of a union at a plant meeting regarding an ongoing unionization 
  campaign.Â  At the meeting, Pactivâ€™s plant manager, Joseph R. Garrison, Jr., 
  spoke against labor unions and McClain suggested the union be allowed to speak 
  to the workers.Â  
McClain alleges that in the days following 
  the meeting, Pactivâ€™s director of occupational health, Dr. Joseph Berley, called 
  McClainâ€™s former psychiatrist; told him McClain had made threatening statements 
  to employees who did not support the union; â€œpassed along lies, rumors, gossip, 
  and innuendoâ€; and asked about how to get McClain committed.Â  Also, Pactiv employees 
  including Robin Montgomery, Pactivâ€™s head of corporate security, met with officers 
  from the local sheriffâ€™s department.Â  McClain asserts the employees also related 
  false and unsubstantiated statements to the officers.Â  According to Garrison, 
  they were alerting the officers of safety concerns raised by several employees 
  involving McClain.Â  After the meeting, sheriffâ€™s officers discovered an outstanding 
  warrant against McClain, stopped him on his way to work, and took him into custody.Â  

After arresting McClain, officers took him to a 
  hospital.Â  McClain was then involuntarily committed to a mental health facility.Â  
  McClain claims that while he was committed, Berley reported false information 
  to McClainâ€™s treating psychiatrist for the purpose of prolonging his commitment.Â  

Following McClainâ€™s commitment, a probate court 
  found him mentally ill and ordered him to undergo an outpatient treatment program.Â  
  McClain asserts Berley also attempted to affect the outcome of the proceeding 
  by sending a fax to McClainâ€™s physician at the mental facility.Â  
McClain first brought suit in federal court against 
  Pactiv, Berley, other Pactiv employees, and members of the Aiken County Sheriffâ€™s 
  Department.Â  His complaint asserted causes of action under 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 
  and several state law claims including civil conspiracy, false arrest, defamation, 
  abuse of legal process, invasion of privacy, and intentional infliction of emotional 
  distress.Â  Both the Pactiv defendants and the law enforcement defendants were 
  granted summary judgment.Â  The district court found McClain presented no evidence 
  the law enforcement officers acted improperly or violated his constitutional 
  rights.Â  As to the Pactiv employees, the court found there was no evidence linking 
  them to a conspiracy involving the alleged constitutional violations.Â  Specifically, 
  the court held McClain â€œhas not been able to produce any affidavit, deposition, 
  or other form of evidence to support his theory that the Pactiv Individuals 
  were involved in the decision to arrest or commit him.â€Â  
Having granted summary judgment on the federal 
  actions, the court declined to exercise jurisdiction over McClainâ€™s remaining 
  state law claims and dismissed them without prejudice. Â On appeal, the 
  Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district courtâ€™s ruling.Â  
Thereafter, McClain filed this action.Â  The trial court dismissed 
  several defendants and causes of action that are not subjects of this appeal.Â  
  The order on appeal dismissed the remaining claims against Pactiv and Berley 
  and thus ended the action.Â  The court agreed with Pactiv that the intentional 
  infliction of emotional distress claim was barred by the exclusivity provision 
  of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  The court also found McClainâ€™s claims for 
  civil conspiracy, false arrest, abuse of legal process, and invasion of privacy 
  were barred by collateral estoppel because of the order in the federal action.Â  

DISCUSSION
I.Â  Intentional 
  Infliction of Emotional Distress
McClain argues the trial court erred in ruling 
  his claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress was barred by the 
  exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We disagree.
The rights and remedies of an injured worker under 
  the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act constitute the workerâ€™s exclusive remedies against 
  the employer.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540 (1985).Â  Our supreme court has held 
  the intentional infliction of emotional distress constitutes a personal injury 
  that falls within the scope of the act.Â  Loges v. Mack Trucks, Inc., 
  308 S.C. 134, 137, 417 S.E.2d 538, 540 (1992).Â  The court later affirmed and 
  clarified this holding by stating: â€œIt is only when the tortfeasor/co-employee 
  is the â€˜alter egoâ€™ of the employer that the liability falls outside the scope 
  of the Act.â€Â  Dickert v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 311 S.C. 218, 220, 
  428 S.E.2d 700, 701 (1993).Â  The alter ego exception applies only to â€œâ€˜dominant 
  corporate owners and officers.â€™â€Â  Id. at 221, 428 S.E.2d at 701 (quoting 
  2A Larson, Workmenâ€™s Compensation, Â§Â§ 68.21 and 68.22).Â  McClain argues 
  Montgomery and Berley are alter egos of Pactiv and thus the claim is not governed 
  by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Nothing in the record before us suggests 
  either Montgomery or Berley is a dominant corporate owner or officer.Â  We therefore 
  reject McClainâ€™s argument that the alter ego exception applies to this case 
  and hold the trial court correctly dismissed this cause of action as barred 
  by the exclusivity provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
II.Â  Collateral 
  Estoppel
McClain also argues the trial court erred in ruling 
  his remaining claims were barred by collateral estoppel.Â  As to the false arrest, 
  abuse of legal process, and invasion of privacy claims, we agree.Â  As to the 
  civil conspiracy claim, we affirm the dismissal on a different ground.
The doctrine of collateral estoppel, or issue preclusion, 
  serves to prevent a party from relitigating in a subsequent action an issue 
  actually and necessarily litigated and determined in a prior action.Â  Shelton 
  v. Oscar Mayer Foods Corp., 325 S.C. 248, 251, 481 S.E.2d 706, 707 (1997).Â  
  In the current action, the trial court found all of McClainâ€™s remaining claims 
  barred by the district courtâ€™s ruling.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the trial 
  court relied on the following portion of the district courtâ€™s order:

[McClain] alleges that the Pactiv Individuals not only conspired 
  with the Sheriff to have [McClain] picked up by deputies, but that they also 
  conspired to place [McClain] in a mental health facility against his will in 
  order to squelch his pro-union activity.Â  However, [McClain] has not been able 
  to produce any affidavit, deposition or other form of evidence to support 
  his theory that the Pactiv Individuals were involved in the decision to arrest 
  or commit him.Â  Moreover, Sheriff Sellers and Officer Rowland have submitted 
  sworn affidavits in which they declare that the Pactiv Individuals did nothing 
  more than ask for extra security at a personnel meeting and were not involved 
  with the decision to serve the 1995 arrest warrant or to commit [McClain].

(Emphasis added.)
This passage of the district courtâ€™s order was 
  part of its decision that there was no link between the Pactiv employees and 
  the alleged violations of McClainâ€™s constitutional rights.Â  That is, the court 
  found no evidence the Pactiv employees were acting under color of state law.Â  
  Because the district court dismissed McClainâ€™s federal actions, it specifically 
  declined to exercise jurisdiction over his state law claims.Â  Nothing in the 
  district courtâ€™s order can be construed as a conclusive determination of the 
  issues in McClainâ€™s false arrest, abuse of legal process, or invasion of privacy 
  claims.Â  
McClain argues his civil conspiracy action is also not barred 
  by the district courtâ€™s order.Â  He notes that in addition to a conspiracy between 
  law enforcement and Pactiv employees, he also asserted in his complaint that 
  Pactiv and its employees conspired with each other, a matter not decided in 
  any fashion by the district courtâ€™s order.Â  However, McClainâ€™s conspiracy claim 
  cannot survive on this theory, as the law is clear that a corporation cannot 
  conspire with itself.Â  Anderson v. S. Ry. Co., 224 S.C. 65, 69, 77 S.E.2d 
  350, 351 (1953) (holding conspiracy cause of action could not be sustained after 
  involuntary nonsuit and jury verdict left corporation as the only remaining 
  defendant because a corporation cannot conspire with itself); Goble v. Am. 
  Ry. Express Co, 124 S.C. 19, 27-28, 115 S.E 900, 903 (1923) (ruling although 
  a corporationâ€™s agents may render the corporation liable for torts committed 
  in the scope of their employment, an agent or multiple agents may not render 
  the corporation liable for a civil conspiracy involving only corporate agents); 
  16 Am. Jur. 2d Conspiracy Â§ 56 (1998) (noting because a corporation cannot 
  conspire with itself, a civil conspiracy is not possible where the co-conspirators 
  are employer and employee or principal and agent).Â  
We therefore affirm the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal 
  of McClainâ€™s intentional infliction of emotional distress cause of action and 
  his cause of action for civil conspiracy, but reverse the dismissal of his state 
  law causes of action for false arrest, abuse of legal process, and invasion 
  of privacy, and remand these claims to the circuit court.
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
 HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

title: State v. Rogers
description: Rogers appeals his covictions for criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping, and strong arm robbery, arguing (1) the testimony from the deaf victim was improperly elicited, (2) his motion for a new trial should have been granted, (3) a foundation was never laid to admit the victim's purse, (4) a chain of custody was not properly established for the victim's purse, and (5) his sentence to life without parole was unconstitutional.  We affirm.
text:
State v. Rogers


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Heyward Leon Rogers, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3854
Â  Hear June 9, 2004 â€“ Filed August 9, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  Solicitor Donald V. Myers and Assistant Solicitor C. Dayton Riddle, both of 
  Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Heyward Leon Rogers was convicted 
  of two counts of first degree criminal sexual conduct, assault and battery with 
  intent to kill, kidnapping, and strong arm robbery.Â  On appeal, Rogers argues 
  the court erred by (1) allowing the solicitor to ask leading questions during 
  the deaf victimâ€™s direct examination, (2) allowing the victimâ€™s son to serve 
  as her interpreter during cross-examination, (3) failing to grant Rogersâ€™ motion 
  for a mistrial after learning that six jurors were exposed to a newspaper article 
  about the trial, (4) admitting a purse into evidence before the victim identified 
  it, (5) admitting fingerprint results into evidence, and (6) sentencing him 
  to life without parole when his last conviction for a most serious crime was 
  nineteen years prior to this conviction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On the evening of September 28, 
  2002, the victim left a fast food restaurant in West Columbia and was walking 
  toward a video poker parlor when a man pushed her to the ground and raped her.Â  
  The victim fought back and eventually caused her perpetrator to flee by throwing 
  sand in his eyes.Â  When the perpetrator fled, he took with him the victimâ€™s 
  purse and her newly purchased food.Â Â  A police officer on patrol found the victim 
  shaking and crying on the side of the road, and he called an ambulance.Â  The 
  victim was transported to the hospital where a rape protocol kit was prepared.Â  
  A week later, the victim helped the police draw a composite sketch of her assailant, 
  which was used to arrest Rogers.Â  
The victim, who was fifty-seven years old at the time 
  of the attack, has been deaf since the age of eight.Â  As a result, her speech 
  is difficult to understand, and she communicates through some vocalization combined 
  with gestures.Â  Because of this unique system of communication, both the solicitor 
  and Rogersâ€™ counsel had problems eliciting testimony from the victim at trial.Â  
  To cope with the problems, the trial court allowed the extensive use of leading 
  questions during the victimâ€™s direct examination.Â  During cross-examination, 
  however, leading questions alone did not facilitate communication between the 
  victim and defense counsel.Â  Thus, the court found it necessary to allow the 
  victimâ€™s son to serve as an interpreter. 
Rogers was convicted on all charges and sentenced 
  concurrently to fifteen years for robbery and four sentences of life without 
  possibility of parole for the other charges.Â  We affirm.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to 
  review errors of law only. We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings 
  unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 
  545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (citation omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rogers raises 
  six issues on appeal:Â  (1) the failure to appoint an interpreter during the 
  victimâ€™s direct-examination; (2) the use of the victimâ€™s son as an interpreter 
  during the victimâ€™s cross-examination; (3) the denial of a motion for new trial 
  after discovering jury misconduct; (4) the admission of the victimâ€™s purse into 
  evidence; (5) the admission of fingerprint evidence; and (6) the propriety of 
  a life without parole sentence. 

  1.     Victimâ€™s direct examination. 
   

Rogers first argues the trial 
  court erred in failing to supply an interpreter for the victim during direct 
  examination.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review. Â 
Because of the victimâ€™s communication 
  problems, the trial court allowed the solicitor to use leading questions.Â  Defense 
  counsel repeatedly objected to the use of leading questions; however, counsel 
  never objected to the courtâ€™s failure to appoint an interpreter, nor did counsel 
  recommend an interpreter be appointed. Â Now, Rogers asks this court to 
  find error in the trial courtâ€™s failure to do what was never asked of it.
â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue 
  cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to 
  and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder 
  Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  â€œThere are 
  four basic requirements to preserving issues at trial for appellate review.Â  
  The issue must have been (1) raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, (2) 
  raised by the appellant, (3) raised in a timely manner, and (4) raised to the 
  trial court with sufficient specificity.â€Â  Jean Hoefer Toal et al., Appellate 
  Practice in South Carolina 57 (2d ed. 2002).
Here, Rogers never raised 
  the issue of using an interpreter during direct examination to the trial court.Â  
  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  

  2.     Victimâ€™s cross-examination  

Rogers also argues the 
  trial court erred by failing to supply the victim with a qualified interpreter 
  during cross-examination.Â  Rogers contends the interpreter was not qualified 
  because he was the victimâ€™s son.Â  We disagree.
Soon 
  after Rogersâ€™ counsel began cross-examining the victim, it became apparent that 
  the victim could not understand many of counselâ€™s questions.Â  When the victim 
  did comprehend the questions, defense counsel could not understand her responses.Â  
  Because of these problems, the solicitor offered the victimâ€™s sister and the 
  victimâ€™s son as interpreters, as they were the only two people available who 
  could interpret the victimâ€™s unique method of communication.Â  Defense counsel 
  objected to the use of the sister because she was also a witness in the case.Â  
  Counsel also objected to the son because he was related to the victim.Â  The 
  court appointed the victimâ€™s son as interpreter, after finding that it was in 
  the best interest of the witness and in the best interest of justice.Â  Â We 
  find no error in this decision.
Section 
  15-27-15 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) regulates the use of interpreters 
  in criminal proceedings.Â  This section requires the use of qualified interpreters, 
  who are defined in part as not being family members of the deaf witness.Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-27-15(B)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  However, the requirement of a qualified 
  interpreter can be waived by the deaf person or by the judge in the fulfillment 
  of justice.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-27-15(A) (Supp. 2003).Â Â  Specifically, the 
  statute states that â€œ[i]f a person elects to use an interpreter other than a 
  qualified interpreter provided for in this section, the court must first make 
  a determination that this action is in the best interest of the individual and 
  is in the best interests of justice.â€Â  In this case, the trial court understood 
  the required findings and made the determination that the use of the victimâ€™s 
  son as interpreter was in the best interest of the victim and of justice.
The trial court was confronted 
  with a difficult situation at trial and fashioned a solution that protected 
  the interests of the victim and justice (as the statute governing interpreters 
  requires) while also affording Rogers with a means to cross-examine his accuser.Â Â  
  Thus, we find no error.

  3.     Trial Publicity  

Rogers next argues the 
  trial court erred when it denied his motion for new trial after jury misconduct 
  was discovered.Â  We disagree.
During the course of the 
  trial, it came to the courtâ€™s attention that a newspaper containing an article 
  about the ongoing trial was in the jury room.Â  At the beginning of proceedings 
  on the day of the articleâ€™s publication, the trial court spent considerable 
  time questioning the jury if any members had either read, seen, or had the article 
  mentioned to them.Â  Six jurors answered these questions in the affirmative.Â  
  These six jurors were then questioned individually by the court.Â Â  Three of 
  them had not even seen the article, but had been apprised of its existence by 
  others.Â  These three jurors stated that they did not read or discuss the article 
  because it would have been inappropriate.Â  They further testified they had not 
  formed any opinion in this case as a result of this limited exposure to the 
  articleâ€™s existence. 
The three other jurors 
  all stated they had looked at the article.Â  One juror stated he saw the headline 
  of the article, but did not read it because of the courtâ€™s instructions.Â  He 
  further said he did not see anyone in the jury room read the paper and nothing 
  had caused him to form an opinion in this case.Â  Another juror admitted that 
  she was to blame for bringing the newspaper into the jury room.Â  She explained 
  that when a fellow juror told her the newspaper contained an article on the 
  trial, she found the appropriate section of the newspaper, folded it, and placed 
  it in her purse. During this action, she said she was only exposed to the headline.Â  
  This juror also testified nothing caused her to form an opinion in this case. 

Finally, the sixth juror 
  admitted she scanned the article though she did not remember any information 
  regarding Rogers.Â  Importantly, she remembered having read details in a paragraph 
  following one referencing Rogersâ€™ prior record.Â  As a result, the judge excused 
  this juror.Â Â  
â€œThe granting or refusing of 
  a motion for a mistrial lies within the sound discretion of the trial court 
  whose ruling will not be disturbed on appeal in the absence of an abuse of discretion 
  amounting to an error of law.â€ 
  State v. Wasson, 299 S.C. 508, 510, 386 S.E.2d 255, 256 (1989).Â  
  In evaluating news articles appearing during trial, the trial court must determine 
  if they are prejudicial and whether jurors read the articles.Â  Id. at 
  511, 386 S.E.2d at 256.Â  If such prejudicial exposure has occurred, the court 
  must craft an appropriate curative measure.Â  Id.Â  In Wasson, our 
  supreme court affirmed the denial of a mistrial where two jurors had read an 
  article discussing the defendantâ€™s other pending charges because the jurors 
  had stated the article did not affect their decision to find the defendant guilty.Â  
  Id. at 511, 386 S.E.2d at 257.
In this case, five of the six 
  jurors had very limited exposure to the article, and all testified it had not 
  caused them to form any opinions.Â  The final juror was dismissed because she 
  had read most of the article.Â  We find the trial court thoroughly evaluated 
  each jurorâ€™s exposure to the news article and took the appropriate measures 
  to safeguard Rogersâ€™ right to a fair trial.Â  Therefore, we find no error.

  4.     Admission of victimâ€™s purse 
   

Rogers next argues that the 
  admission of the victimâ€™s purse into evidence was error because it had not been 
  identified by the victim.Â  We disagree.
The purse 
  was entered into evidence during the testimony of Mark Jones, the police officer 
  who retrieved the purse after a homeowner called and reported finding it in 
  his yard.Â  The purse was admitted at trial after Jones testified that it was 
  the purse he retrieved, that the purse matched a description given by the victim, 
  and that it contained an item displaying the victimâ€™s name.Â  The victimâ€™s description 
  of the missing purse and the discovery of items bearing her name within it link 
  the purse to the victim and the crime.Â  Therefore, admission of the purse at 
  that time was not erroneous.Â  
Moreover, 
  the victim eventually identified the purse as belonging to her.Â  Thus, even 
  if the purse had been admitted without a proper foundation, the foundation was 
  ultimately provided, and there would be no prejudice to Rogers.Â  See 
  State v. Pollard, 261 S.C. 389, 200 S.E.2d 233 (1973) (finding no prejudice 
  where drugs were entered into evidence prior to testimony of a complete chain 
  of custody because the chain was eventually provided); see also Rule 
  104(b), SCRE (allowing admission of evidence subject to the introduction of 
  other supporting evidence).Â  Therefore, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s 
  admission of the purse into evidence.

  5.     Admission of fingerprint evidence 
   

Rogers also argues the trial 
  court erred by allowing fingerprint results into evidence without a proper chain 
  of custody.Â  We disagree.
Rogersâ€™ fingerprint was found 
  on a slip of paper in the victimâ€™s purse and these results were entered into 
  evidence through the testimony of a fingerprint analyst.Â  Rogers contends the 
  evidence should be excluded because the purseâ€™s chain of custody was defective.Â  

Initially, we note that because 
  the purse is a non-fungible piece of evidence, chain of custody is not required 
  for its admission.Â  State v. Glenn, 328 S.C. 300, 305, 492 S.E.2d 393, 
  395 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œ[W]here the issue is the admissibility of non-fungible 
  evidence â€“ that is, evidence that is unique and identifiable â€“ the establishment 
  of a strict chain of custody is not required . . . .â€).Â  However, even if a 
  chain needed to be established, it had been.Â  At trial, every individual who 
  had possession of the purse, which contained the slip of paper, testified to 
  having it and denied tampering with it.Â  
Rogers points to a period of 
  one week when law enforcement had returned the purse to the victim before retrieving 
  the purse again and performing fingerprint tests on its contents.Â  Apparently, 
  Rogersâ€™ concern is that some form of tampering might have occurred while it 
  was in the victimâ€™s possession.Â  However, the proof of chain of custody does 
  not have to negate all possibility of tampering.Â  The State only needs to establish 
  a complete chain of evidence as far as practicable.Â  Id.Â  The period 
  of time during which the purse was returned to the victim is accounted for by 
  the testimony of the victimâ€™s sister, who lives with the victim.Â  The sister 
  testified that during the week the purse was in her home, the bag containing 
  the purse was never opened.Â  Additionally, the officer who returned the purse 
  testified that when she went to retrieve it, the bag containing the purse was 
  where she had left it. 
South Carolina law does not 
  require testimony as to the exclusion of any possibility of tampering.Â  Rather, 
  â€œwhere the identity of persons handling the specimen is established, . . . evidence 
  regarding its care goes only to the weight of the specimen as credible evidence,â€ 
  not to the admissibility of the evidence.Â  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 
  419, 424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837  (2001).Â  Accordingly, we find no error in 
  the admission of the fingerprint results.

  6.     Life without parole 
   

Finally, Rogers argues a sentence 
  of life without parole is cruel and unusual punishment under this set of facts.Â  
  We disagree.
Rogers was sentenced to life 
  without parole pursuant to section 17-25-45(A) of the South Carolina Code.Â Â  
  Section 17-25-45(A) requires that â€œupon a conviction for a most serious offense 
  . . . a person must be sentenced to a term of imprisonment for life without 
  the possibility of parole if that person has one or more prior convictions for: 
  (1) a most serious offense.â€Â  
Nineteen years prior to the 
  convictions addressed in this opinion, Rogers was convicted of assault and battery 
  with intent to kill, which is a â€œmost serious offense.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(1) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  However, Rogers argues this prior offense was too remote in time 
  to be used to enhance his sentence for the current crime.Â  
In State v. Burdette, 
  335 S.C. 34, 37-38, 515 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1999), the supreme court affirmed imposing 
  a life without parole sentence where the appellantâ€™s prior offense occurred 
  seventeen years before the triggering offense, just two years less than the 
  span of time in our case.Â  Furthermore, section 17-25-45(A) has withstood repeated 
  constitutional challenges, including assertions of cruel and unusual punishment.Â  
  See, e.g., State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 56-59, 543 S.E.2d 
  541, 545-47 (2001) (holding â€œtwo-strikesâ€ law constitutional under separation 
  of powers, cruel and unusual punishment, equal protection and ex post facto 
  challenges).Â  Thus, we find no error in imposing a life without parole sentence 
  in this case.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, 
  Rogersâ€™ convictions and sentences are
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, 
  J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.
