title: State v. Slater
description: Lord Byron Slater appeals his murder conviction, arguing the trial judge erred by not including a self-defense charge. We reverse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Byron B. Slater, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3855Â Â 
Heard April 7, 2004 â€“ Filed August 9, 2004 

Â Â Â Â Â Â  REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald 
  J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Byron Slater appeals his conviction 
  on a murder charge, alleging, inter alia, that the trial court erred 
  in failing to charge the jury on self-defense. We reverse and remand. 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  FACTS
Appellant Byron Slater was with some friends on 
  the evening of February 3, 2001, at a school gymnasium where there had been 
  a dance. Following the dance, Slater went outside, where he started talking 
  with â€œsome females.â€ While there, he became aware of a disturbance near a truck. 
  Slater walked to his car, retrieved a gun, and started to walk toward the truck. [1]  Slater then changed his mind. He walked back 
  toward his car, where three friends, Ellis Judon (the driver), Kenyon Nichols, 
  and Deshawn Brown, were waiting for him. Moments later, Slater noticed that 
  another disturbance was taking place in an adjacent parking lot and wanted to 
  see what was going on. Slater asked Judon to drive there. [2]  In that second parking lot, an apparent robbery 
  was unfolding. The victim was on the ground, being stomped by five men. Slater 
  knew neither the victim nor his attackers. 
Slater testified that he walked up to the robbery 
  and surprised one of the attackers. The man then turned around and pointed a 
  gun toward Slater. Slater quickly turned around and started running back toward 
  his car. As he ran, he heard a gunshot and responded by shooting his own gun 
  behind him. Slater got into the car where his friends were waiting for him. [3]  He continued shooting in the air as the car 
  pulled away. In the ensuing chaos, the victim of the attempted robbery lay dying 
  on the ground. He had been shot twice.Â  
Back in the car, Slater said that he thought he 
  had â€œhitâ€ someone. Slater and his three friends drove to Slaterâ€™s house, where 
  Slater left the gun. The four then went back to the parking lot where the shooting 
  had occurred. On the way, the police stopped them and searched the car but did 
  not find any weapon. 
Early the next morning, detectives from the city 
  of North Charleston went to Slaterâ€™s residence to arrest him. Following the 
  arrest, they obtained a search warrant for Slaterâ€™s house. The detectives recovered 
  various ammunitions from Slaterâ€™s yard and from inside his house, including 
  two guns, some projectiles, bullets, and shell casings. 
At the police station, Slater told the police that 
  he â€œdidnâ€™t shoot anybody.â€ However, a ballistics expert testified at trial that 
  the fatal bullets came from Slaterâ€™s gun, as did the ones retrieved from the 
  crime scene. Additionally, numerous witnesses placed Slater at the crime scene 
  with a gun. Slater himself admitted to shooting his gun, but insisted that he 
  did not mean to shoot anyone. The jury convicted Slater of murder, though the 
  trial judge had included a manslaughter option in the jury charge. [4]  The trial judge expressly refused to include 
  a self-defense charge. 
 
  ISSUES

  
    
      
         I.  
        Did the trial judge err in refusing to include a self-defense charge, reasoning 
  that Slater had brought about the difficulty?
      
      
         II.  
         
  Did the trial judge err in allowing the victimâ€™s mother to testify that her 
  son did not have a criminal record?
      
      
         III. 
         
  Did the trial judge err in allowing a detective to testify that an eyewitness 
  to the crime had denied hearing any gunshot other than Slaterâ€™s?
      
    
  

    LAW/ANALYSIS
Slater argues that the trial judge committed reversible 
  error in refusing to include a self-defense charge. We agree.
The evidence presented at 
  trial determines the law to be charged. State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 
  280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994). If there is any evidence in the record 
  to support self-defense, the issue should be submitted to the jury. State 
  v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 302 (2002); State v. 
  Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 261, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993). A trial judgeâ€™s failure 
  to do so is reversible error. State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 416, 535 S.E.2d 
  431, 434 (2000). Additionally, â€œ[c]urrent law requires the State to disprove 
  self-defense, once raised by the defendant, beyond a reasonable doubt.â€ Burkhart, 
  350 S.C. at 261, 565 S.E.2d at 303 (citing State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 
  538, 544, 500 S.E.2d 489, 494 (1998)). 
For a defendant to argue self-defense, 
  the record must demonstrate that â€œ(1) [he] was without fault in bringing on 
  the difficulty; (2) [he] actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing 
  his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) a reasonably prudent person 
  of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the same belief; and 
  (4) [he] had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.â€ State v. Chapman, 
  336 S.C. 149, 153, 519 S.E.2d 100, 103 (1999).Â  Moreover, â€œ[o]ne who provokes 
  or initiates an assault cannot escape criminal liability by invoking self-defense.â€ 
  State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 345, 520 S.E.2d 319, 322 (1999). However, 
  a defendant can restore his right to self-defense if he withdraws from the conflict 
  and communicates that decision to the opponent. Id.Â  
Here, there was some evidence to support 
  a self-defense charge. Slater maintains that when he approached the altercation 
  between the victim and his attackers, an attacker pointed a gun at Slater. Slater 
  then turned and ran. While running away, Slater heard gunshots and returned 
  fire, not looking in the direction where he was firing. Slater testified, â€œwhen 
  I walked up on him, I guess I surprised him and he turned to me and he had a 
  gun in his hand. And I see his gun and I started running.â€ He added, â€œYeah, 
  when I walked up on him like here, like he turned to me, like had the gun pointed 
  at me like he surprised.â€ Additionally, Mark Nelson, a friend of the victim, 
  testified that he saw one of the attackers â€“ someone other than Slater â€“ with 
  a gun. 
The State insists that Slater bears some responsibility 
  for the tragedy because he was in unlawful possession of a gun and carried that 
  gun into the altercation. However, the mere unlawful possession of a firearm, 
  with nothing more, does not automatically bar a self-defense charge. See 
  State v. Burris, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999) (explaining 
  that â€œa person can be acting lawfully, even if he is in unlawful possession 
  of a weaponâ€). As importantly, Slater testified that he turned and started to 
  run away from the attacker holding the gun. Therefore, even if Slater 
  initially contributed to the difficulty, that he turned and ran away would restore 
  his right to self-defense. See Bryant, 336 S.C. at 346, 520 S.E.2d 
  at 322 (explaining that an appellantâ€™s attempt to leave the scene of a confrontation 
  would signal that the â€œappellant truly intended to withdrawâ€ from the situation). 
  See also State v. Rogers, 329 S.C. 520, 525, 466 S.E.2d 360, 363 
  (1996) (reasoning that Rogers faced no overt threat because his opponent was 
  moving away from him and said nothing to evince a threat).Â  
The dissent contends that Slater â€œprovoked a conflict 
  by running toward an altercation while conspicuously holding a cocked and loaded 
  gun.â€ The record provides otherwise. Slater testified, â€œI walked up on [the 
  attacker] . . . [the gun] was by my side . . . in my right hand.â€ That testimony 
  is uncontroverted. The dissent apparently assumes that (1) one of the attackers 
  saw Slaterâ€™s gun; (2) was afraid for his own safety; and (3) started to shoot 
  as a result. That scenario is plausible, but the record fails to establish it. 
  [5]  It is just as likely that Slaterâ€™s gun was inconspicuous, especially 
  given that the regrettable events of that evening occurred when â€œit was pretty 
  darkâ€ and that Slater had his gun by his side.
Citing Bryant, the dissent argues that â€œSlater 
  failed to effectively communicate his intent to withdrawâ€ to the attacker with 
  the gun. We disagree. In Bryant, the victim apparently caught the appellant 
  breaking into the victimâ€™s truck. Id. at 343, 520 S.E.2d at 321. The 
  two struggled, and the appellant stabbed the victim to death with a screwdriver. 
  Id. at 344, 520 S.E.2d at 321. The appellant argued that he was entitled 
  to a self-defense charge because he had dropped his knife to the ground before 
  the fight began. Id. According to him, that gesture indicated his intent 
  to withdraw and restored his right to self-defense. Id. Our supreme court 
  rejected the argument. 
The court initially found that the appellant brought on the 
  difficulty because the attempted break-in was â€œin violation of law and reasonably 
  calculated to produce the occasion.â€ Id. at 345, 520 S.E.2d at 322. The 
  court clarified, however, that, â€œâ€˜[i]f, after commencing the assault, the aggressor 
  withdraws in good faith from the conflict and announces in some way to his adversary 
  his intention to retire, he is restored to his right of self-defense.â€™â€ Id. 
  (citation omitted). In that case, the appellant himself admitted that the victim 
  did not see him drop the knife, and therefore could not have known about the 
  alleged withdrawal. The court reasoned, as said earlier, that â€œ[i]f appellant 
  truly intended to withdraw he could have easily left the open parking lot.â€ 
  Id. at 346, 520 S.E.2d at 322. 
Here, Slater merely walked toward the altercation; he threatened 
  or assaulted no one. [6]  More 
  importantly, Slater immediately â€œturned and ranâ€ after seeing the attackerâ€™s 
  gun. Slater did exactly what the supreme court looked for in Bryant: 
  he left â€“ quickly.Â  
Admittedly, as the dissent posits, the attacker may have 
  thought that Slater was withdrawing simply â€œto gain [some] tactical advantage.â€ 
  However, our task is not to determine the attackerâ€™s state of mind. Rather, 
  as instructed by our supreme court, we are to see only whetherÂ  â€œany evidenceâ€ 
  in the record supports a self-defense charge. [7]  Day, 341 S.C. at 416, 
  535 S.E.2d at 434. We find that there is some. The trial judge, therefore, erred 
  in not including the charge. 
Having found that the exclusion of the 
  requested self-defense charge was error, we need not address Slaterâ€™s remaining 
  issues.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we reverse and remand 
  for a new trial on both charges. [8] 
  
ANDERSON, J., concurs and HEARN, C.J., dissents 
  separately.
 
 HEARN, C.J., dissenting: Because 
  Slater failed to effectively communicate his intent to withdraw after he provoked 
  a dangerous situation, I do not believe he was entitled to a charge of self-defense.Â  
  Therefore, I respectfully dissent. 
A person who provokes an assault cannot 
  claim a right to self-defense unless that person â€œâ€˜withdraws in good faith from 
  the conflict and announces in some way to his adversary his intention to retire.â€™â€Â  
  State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 345, 520 S.E.2d 319, 322 (1999) (quoting 
  55 A.L.R.3d at 1003).Â  Here, all the evidence, including Slaterâ€™s own testimony, 
  indicates that he provoked a conflict by running toward an altercation while 
  conspicuously holding a cocked and loaded handgun, even though he had no personal 
  connection to the people involved in the fight. [9] Â  
Slater argues that he withdrew from the conflict 
  because (1) he began to run when a man involved in the turmoil pointed a gun 
  at him, and (2) he did not shoot his gun until he heard someone else fire first.Â  
  However, in his testimony, Slater admitted that the events - his running, hearing 
  the shot, and firing back - all â€œhappened so fast.â€Â  Slater further admitted 
  that he not only shot backwards as he was running away, but that he also shot 
  in the air after he had gotten inside a car and was riding away from the scene.Â  
  In my view, even if Slater intended to withdraw, neither his words nor his actions 
  communicated this intent. See id. (â€œOneâ€™s right to self-defense 
  is restored after a withdrawal from the initial difficulty with the victim if 
  that withdrawal is communicated to the victim by word or act.â€); State v. 
  Graham, 260 S.C. 449, 196 S.E.2d 495 (1973).Â  
While the trial court is required to charge the 
  jury on self-defense if there is any evidence supporting the charge, all the 
  evidence in the record shows that Slater provoked a dangerous situation and 
  no evidence indicates that he ever communicated his withdrawal after the
provocation.Â  Despite Slaterâ€™s claim that he attempted 
  to retreat, he admitted that he still had a cocked and loaded gun in his hand.Â  
  With a dangerous weapon readily available for Slater to use, the person whom 
  Slater had approached could not have known whether Slater was withdrawing from 
  the conflict or whether Slater was retreating to gain tactical advantage.Â  See 
  40 C.J.S. Homicide Â§ 125 (1991) (â€œAs long as a person keeps his gun in 
  his hand prepared to shoot, the person opposing him is not expected or required 
  to accept any act or statement as indicative of an intent to discontinue the 
  assault.â€); see also Bryant, 336 S.C. at 346, 520 S.E.2d at 322 
  (finding the defendant failed to effectively communicate his withdrawal even 
  though he threw down his knife because the defendant admitted the victim did 
  not see him drop the knife).Â  Because Slater failed to communicate his intent 
  to withdraw, his right to use self-defense was never restored.Â  Therefore, I 
  find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge self-defense.
Because I disagree with the majorityâ€™s 
  decision to reverse on the failure to charge self-defense, I briefly address 
  Slaterâ€™s additional arguments on appeal.Â  In addition to his argument regarding 
  self-defense, Slater also contends the trial court erred by allowing the victimâ€™s 
  mother to testify that her son did not have a criminal record.Â  
Rule 404(a)(2), SCRE, states that although character 
  evidence is generally not allowed, â€œ[e]vidence of a character trait of peacefulness 
  of the victim offered by the prosecution in a homicide case [is admissible when 
  it is used] to rebut evidence that the victim was the first aggressor.â€Â  Here, 
  because the gist of Slaterâ€™s defense at trial was that he had been shot at first, 
  evidence regarding the victimâ€™s character was properly offered to rebut the 
  inference that the victim may have been the initial shooter. 
  [10]  Therefore, I find no error in the trial court allowing this testimony.
Slaterâ€™s final argument on appeal is that the trial 
  court erred by admitting hearsay testimony of a police officer.Â  I disagree.
At trial, Deshawn Brown, who was accompanying Slater on 
  the night of the incident, testified he heard a gunshot earlier in the evening 
  when he and Slater were â€œstanding by the school by the gym.â€ Â On redirect examination, 
  Brown testified that he remembered giving a statement to the police.Â  When asked 
  whether he told the investigating officers that he heard gunshots earlier that 
  night, Brown replied that he did not. Â Brown explained that he never told anyone 
  about the gunshots he heard because, until the trial, he had never been asked 
  about hearing any other gunshots that night. 
At a later point in Slaterâ€™s trial, the State 
  questioned one of the officers who had questioned Brown, and the following exchange 
  occurred:

  
    
      
        Q:
         Did you ask them about guns at the scene of the crime?
      
      
        A:Â 
         Yes, I did.
      
      
        Q:Â 
         Did you ask them about anybody else shooting at the 
  scene of the crime?
      
      
        A:
         Yes, I did.
      
      
        Q: 
         Well, when you were interviewing Deshawn Brown, did 
  he ever tell you that he heard anybody else shooting out there?
      
      
        Defense Counsel:Â  
         Objection, your Honor, thatâ€™s not proper.
      
      
        The Court:Â 
         No, sir, I will â€“ no, sir, Iâ€™ll permit that 
  question.Â  Go ahead.
      
      
        Q:Â  
        Did he ever tell you
          that?
      
      
        A: 
        I interviewed Deshawn Brown.Â  He never once told us 
  about anybody else shooting at the scene.
      
    
  

Slater contends on appeal that the above testimony was inadmissible 
  hearsay because it refers to a statement â€œother than one made by the declarant 
  while testifying at trial or hearing, offered into evidence to prove the truth 
  of the matter asserted.â€Â  See Rule 801(c), SCRE.
While the above testimony regarding the statements 
  of Brown is hearsay, we find that it is admissible under Rule 613(b), SCRE.Â  
  This rule provides, in pertinent part:

Extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement by 
  a witness is not admissible unless the witness is advised of the substance of 
  the statement, the time and place it was allegedly made, and the person to whom 
  it was made, and is given the opportunity to explain or deny the statement.Â  
  If a witness does not admit that he has made the prior inconsistent statement, 
  extrinsic evidence of such statement is admissible.

Rule 613(b), SCRE (emphasis added).Â  When a witness is presented 
  with the requisite circumstances surrounding an alleged inconsistent statement 
  and nevertheless continues to deny before the court ever making the statement, 
  another personâ€™s testimony that the witness did, in fact, make that statement 
  is admissible under Rule 613(b), SCRE.Â  See State v. Fossick, 
  333 S.C. 66, 69-70, 508 S.E.2d 32, 33 (1998).
In the case before us, the investigating officer 
  testified that he asked all the witnesses (including Brown) about whether anyone 
  else was shooting a weapon at the scene of the crime.Â  He testified Brown had 
  not told him about anyone else shooting.Â  Because Brown denied ever being asked 
  this question after he was presented with all the requisite circumstances, the 
  officerâ€™s testimony constituted extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement 
  and was admissible under Rule 613(b).Â  Thus, the judge acted properly in overruling 
  Slaterâ€™s objections to the testimony.
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, I 
  would affirm Slaterâ€™s conviction.

 
   
    [1]  Slater testified that he retrieved the gun â€œto shoot it in the air 
    . . . something that young people be doing like after parties or clubs or 
    whatever.â€

 
   
     
    [2]    There is some dispute as to these facts. Slater contends that he 
    never returned to his car because he realized another confrontation was taking 
    place in another parking lot and walked over there instead, still carrying 
    his gun. 

 
   
    [3]  Nichols and Brown, too, had gotten out of the car, but apparently 
    returned before Slater.

 
   
    [4]  The jury also convicted Slater on one count of possession of a firearm 
    during the commission of a violent crime.

 
   
    [5]  The men involved in the robbery were apparently never apprehended. 
    They did not participate in the proceedings, so what they may have seen is 
    unclear.

 
   
    [6]  If the gun was indeed inconspicuous (see earlier discussion), it 
    is difficult to imagine how Slaterâ€™s act of walking toward the robbery was 
    â€œin violation of law and reasonably calculated to produceâ€ the difficulty. 
    The cases cited by the Bryant court all involved robbers or other felons 
    claiming self-defense when the would-be victims tried to defend themselves. 
    See id. at 345, 520 S.E.2d at 322.

 
   [7]  Additionally, the supreme court 
    cautioned that â€œa trial judge should specifically tailor the self-defense 
    instruction to adequately reflect the facts and theories presented by the 
    defendant.â€ Day, 341 S.C. at 418, 535 S.E.2d at 435.

 
   
    [8]  See Burkhart, 350 S.C. at 264, 565 S.E.2d at 304 (ordering 
    a new trial on charges of possession of a firearm during the commission of 
    a violent crime after overturning the underlying conviction on the violent 
    crime).

 
   
    [9]  Slater made no claim of â€œdefense of others at trial,â€ nor did his 
    testimony in any way reflect an intention to enter the conflict in defense 
    of those being attacked.

 
   [10]  After the victimâ€™s mother testified, Slater 
    presented testimony that powder residue on the victimâ€™s hands could have resulted 
    from the victim firing a weapon, further indicating that the defenseâ€™s strategy 
    was to implicate the victim as the initial shooter.

description: Husband and Wife were divorced pursuant to an order requiring Husband to pay Wife alimony "for a period of the earlier of seven years or upon the remarraiage of [Wife]." THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        
Paul V. Degenhart,       
Appellant,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        
Debra V. Burriss (f/k/a Debra V.
Degenhart),        Respondent.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Walter B. Brown, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3856
Heard June 24, 2004 â€“ Filed August 16, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Mark Taylor and M. Ronald McMahan, Jr., both of West Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Sandra R. Parise, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Paul V. Degenhart appeals 
  a family court order denying his request for termination of alimony.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Paul V. Degenhart and Debra V. 
  Burriss were married in 1989.Â  The couple separated and entered into a written 
  separation agreement in August 1999. Â Following one year of separation, 
  they were divorced.Â  The final divorce order incorporated the written separation 
  agreement verbatim.Â  The section of this agreement pertaining to alimony reads 
  as follows:

Husband agrees to pay Wife alimony in the amount of $2,500.00 
  per month payable on the 1st day of each month beginning with the 
  month of September, 1999 for a period of the earlier of seven years or upon 
  the remarriage of Wife.Â  

Under the heading â€œModification and Binding Effect 
  of Agreement,â€ the agreement provides:

The provisions of this AGREEMENT shall not be modified or 
  changed except by mutual consent and agreement of the parties expressed in writing.Â  


Prior to the coupleâ€™s divorce, but after 
  entering into the separation agreement, Wife met William R. Hall.Â  The two began 
  spending the night together on a regular basis in November 1999, and they continue 
  to share an exclusive sexual relationship.Â  Wife and Hall began cohabitating 
  in a rental house in September 2000, around the time of Husband and Wifeâ€™s divorce.Â  
  One year later, Wife and Hall purchased a home.Â  The house was jointly titled 
  and mortgaged, and the two equally divided the down payment and the tax deduction 
  for the mortgage interest.Â  Additionally, they have taken numerous vacations 
  together.Â  Despite their sexual relationship and cohabitation, Wife and Hall 
  maintain separate bank accounts and do not hold themselves out to be married. 

In August 2002, Husband initiated the underlying 
  action for termination of his alimony obligation, based solely on the cohabitation 
  of Wife and Hall.Â  The family court denied his request, and Husband appeals. 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Questions concerning alimony rest within the sound 
  discretion of the family court judge whose conclusion will not be disturbed 
  absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 
  221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001); Bannen v.Bannen, 286 S.C. 
  24, 26, 331 S.E.2d 379, 380 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs 
  when the decision is controlled by some error of law or is based on findings 
  of fact that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Bryson, 347 S.C. at 224, 
  553 S.E.2d at 495; McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 
  91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Based on the terms of Husband and 
  Wifeâ€™s agreement and the law of alimony modification, the family court determined 
  it did not have the authority to modify Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  We agree.
Section 20-3-130 of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003) outlines in great detail the nature of alimony awards under 
  South Carolina law.Â  Subsection (G) states in relevant part: â€œThe parties may 
  agree in writing if properly approved by the court to make the payment of alimony 
  as set forth [in this statute] nonmodifiable and not subject to subsequent 
  modification by the court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(G) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis 
  added).Â  While the family court normally has the authority to modify alimony, [1]  once an alimony agreement that specifically 
  disallows modification is approved by the court and merged into a judicial order, 
  it is binding on the parties and the court and is not subject to modification.Â  
  Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 353, 306 S.E.2d 624, 627 (1983) (â€œThe 
  parties may specifically agree that the amount of alimony may not ever be modified 
  by the court . . . .â€); Croom v. Croom, 305 S.C. 158, 161, 406 S.E.2d 
  381, 383 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  
In Croom, this court reversed the 
  modification of an alimony obligation because the court-adopted alimony agreement 
  provided â€œthe terms and conditions of the agreement and any court order approving 
  it â€˜shall not be modifiable by the parties or any court without written 
  consent of the Husband and Wife.â€™â€Â  305 S.C. at 159, 406 S.E.2d at 382 (emphasis 
  added).Â  Husband would have us find Croom inapposite to the case before 
  us because this agreement lacks language specifically stating that the family 
  court cannot modify the agreement.Â  We disagree.
While this agreement does not expressly 
  state that the family court cannot modify the agreement, it is clear 
  and specific about how the agreement can be modified, that being â€œby 
  mutual consent and agreement of the parties expressed in writing.â€Â  Because 
  the family court â€œmust enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms 
  regardless of its wisdom or folly, apparent unreasonableness, or the partiesâ€™ 
  failure to guard their rights carefully,â€ we see no reason to require â€œmagic 
  wordsâ€ for an unambiguous agreement to gain efficacy.Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 
  328 S.C. 329, 340, 491 S.E.2d 583, 589 (Ct. App. 1997).Â Â Â  The agreement here, 
  by stating that its terms â€œshall not be modified or changed except by mutual 
  consent,â€ clearly denies the family court the jurisdiction to modify the agreement 
  by its own authority or at the behest of only one of the parties.Â  Therefore, 
  it was properly enforced.
Husband also contends that recent case law and 
  amendments to section 20-3-150 of the South Carolina Code may, in certain situations, 
  trump the longstanding rule that alimony agreements can be made nonmodifiable 
  by agreement of the parties.Â  Again, we disagree.Â  
In the case of Bryson v. Bryson, 
  347 S.C. 221, 224-25, 553 S.E.2d 493, 494 (Ct. App. 2001), this court held certain 
  relationships, although not legal marriages, could by their nature constitute 
  relationships â€œtantamount to marriageâ€ and warrant alimony modification pursuant 
  to section 20-3-170.Â  See also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985) (providing 
  that changed circumstances may warrant a modification or termination of alimony).Â  
  A substantial element of determining whether a relationship is tantamount to 
  marriage is the cohabitation of the parties.Â  See Bryson, 347 
  S.C. at 226 n.7, 553 S.E.2d at 496 n.7.Â  Later amendments to section 20-3-150, 
  further defining â€œcohabitationâ€ as previously applied in Bryson, read 
  as follows:

[U]pon the remarriage or continued cohabitation of 
  the supported spouse the amount fixed in the decree for his or her support shall 
  cease, and no further alimony payments may be required from the supporting spouse.
For purposes of this subsection and unless otherwise agreed 
  to in writing by the parties, â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ means the supported spouse 
  resides with another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety 
  or more consecutive days.

(Emphasis added to relevant 2002 amendments.)
We first note that Bryson did not 
  concern an alimony agreement with terms that made the agreement nonmodifiable 
  by the family court and therefore is not specifically applicable to the case 
  at bar.Â  Nothing in this courtâ€™s holding in Bryson changed the longstanding 
  rule that parties could agree to make alimony nonmodifiable.Â  See Bryson, 
  347 S.C. at 224-25, 553 S.E.2d at 495 (â€œThus, the doctrines of law of the case 
  and res judicata do not apply to those family court actions that are modifiable 
  based on changes in circumstances.â€) (emphasis added).Â  Furthermore, because 
  â€œthe legislature cannot create a statute which applies retroactively to divest 
  vested rights,â€ the 2002 amendments to section 20-3-150 have absolutely no bearing 
  on Husband and Wifeâ€™s agreement, which was incorporated into an order in 2000.Â  
  Russo v. Sutton, 310 S.C. 200, 205 n.5, 422 S.E.2d 750, 753 n.5 (1992).
 Accordingly, the order of the family court 
  is
 AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
     
    [1]    See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985) (providing 
    that changed conditions may warrant a modification of alimony); Jeanes 
    v. Jeanes, 255 S.C. 161, 164-65, 177 S.E.2d 537, 538 (1970) (modifying 
    alimony due to cohabitation in a situation where the agreement did not 
    specifically deny the court the authority to do so).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Key Corporate Capital, Inc., National Tax Assistance Corporation, TransAm 
        Tax Certificate Corporation d/b/a Destiny 98TD, Advantage 99TD, TA Escrow 
        97 and Destiny 98,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
County of Beaufort, Treasurer of Beaufort County and Tax Collector of 
        Beaufort County,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No.Â  3857
Heard June 23, 2004 â€“ Filed August 16, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David S. Black and Mary Bass Lohr, both of Beaufort, for Appellants.
James Howarth Ritchie, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This case arises from numerous 
  voided tax sales of real property in Beaufort County.Â  After the sales were 
  voided, the County returned the purchase prices to the successful bidders but 
  refused to return the interest the money had earned.Â Â  The bidders sued and, 
  under a theory of restitution, were awarded an amount equal to the interest 
  earned by Beaufort County during the time it held the biddersâ€™ money.Â  The County 
  appeals.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Key Corporate Capital, Inc., 
  National Tax Assistance Corporation, and TransAm Tax Certificate Corporation 
  (â€œbiddersâ€) purchased a number of properties at Beaufort County tax sales in 
  1998 and 1999.Â  The Beaufort County Treasurer voided twelve of these tax sales 
  pursuant to the authority vested in the Treasurer by section 12-51-150 of the 
  South Carolina Code (2000).Â  The voiding of the tax sales resulted solely from 
  the actions or inactions taken by Beaufort County and its agents.Â  Specifically, 
  the Treasurer discovered a series of â€œerrors, oversights, and/or miscommunications 
  within the Beaufort County offices, meaning the Treasurerâ€™s Office and/or the 
  Auditorâ€™s Office.â€Â  These errors included â€œa deed recording error resulting 
  in an invalid notice to the defaulting taxpayer,â€ a failure to accurately credit 
  the payment of delinquent taxes, and â€œa flaw with regard to statutory notice 
  to the delinquent taxpayer.â€Â Â  
When the tax sales were voided 
  by the County of Beaufort, Treasurer of Beaufort County, and Tax Collector of 
  Beaufort County (â€œthe Countyâ€), the amounts paid for the properties were refunded 
  to the bidders.Â  However, the County retained the purchase price on each property 
  for at least thirty days, and in some cases, the County held the purchase price 
  for over a year. 
The County actually accrued $28,010.93 
  in interest by holding the monies involved in these voided tax sales.Â  The bidders 
  sued the County, arguing that in addition to recouping the amount of their bid, 
  they should also receive the interest their money earned while in the Countyâ€™s 
  possession.Â  The master-in-equity agreed and ruled that under a theory of restitution, 
  the bidders were entitled to the actual interest earned by the County prior 
  to the return of the purchase price.Â Â  We affirm.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen legal and equitable actions are maintained 
  in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes 
  of the applicable standard of review on appeal.â€Â  Kiriakides v. Atlas Food 
  Sys. & Servs., Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580, 527 S.E.2d 371, 375 (Ct. App. 
  2000) (quoting Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92 n.1, 485 S.E.2d 
  97, 99 n.1 (1997).Â  â€œIn an action at equity, this court can find facts in accordance 
  with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  West v. Newberry Elec. 
  Co-op., 357 S.C. 537, 542, 593 S.E.2d 500, 502 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
  â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate court standard of 
  review extends only to the correction of errors of law.â€Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. 
  v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The County first argues that section 12-51-150 
  of the South Carolina Code (2000), which governs voided tax sales, compels our 
  court to allow the County to retain the interest while holding a successful 
  bidderâ€™s money. Â We disagree.
Section 12-51-150 states:
In the case that the official in charge of the tax sale 
  discovers before a tax title has passed, the failure of any action required 
  to be properly performed, the official may void the tax sale and refund the 
  amount paid to the successful bidder.

The County argues that because this section only 
  addresses the return of the purchase price upon the voiding of a tax sale, the 
  statute allows the County to keep the interest earned on the money.Â  However, 
  we do not believe the statuteâ€™s silence on the subject entitles the County to 
  retain the interest.Â  

In contrast to section 12-51-150â€™s silence, other 
  code sections relevant to tax sales address which party is entitled to interest 
  in certain situations.Â  For instance, under section 12-51-130, the County 
  is â€œentitled to the earnings for keeping the overage [amount paid at auction 
  greater than the amounts owed by delinquent taxpayer].â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-130 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 12-51-100, however, provides that a successful bidder 
  is entitled to receive interest on the bid price in the event the property is 
  redeemed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-100 (2000).Â  Because other statutes are explicit 
  about which party is entitled to keep interest on bid prices from tax sales, 
  the silence of section 12-51-150 does not, by itself, indicate the Legislatureâ€™s 
  intent. 
The County also argues that, because section 12-51-150 
  does not specifically grant bidders the right to recoup the interest the County 
  earns on their money, the County is entitled to the interest pursuant to the 
  supreme courtâ€™s decision in Red Oak Lands, Inc. v. Lane, 268 S.C. 631, 
  235 S.E.2d 718 (1977).Â  We disagree.
In the Red Oak Lands case, a corporation 
  (Red Oak) bought property at a tax sale but was later divested of title to that 
  property.Â Â  Red Oak sued the tax collector for the damages it sustained from 
  this divestment pursuant to sections 65-2782 through 65-2785 of the South Carolina 
  Code (1962), which entitled a divested tax sale purchaser to a lien on the property 
  for the amount paid at the tax sale or to recover that amount directly from 
  the taxing authority.Â Â  These statutes, however, required the divested tax sale 
  purchaser to bring suit against the taxing authority within two years of the 
  sale.Â  Id. at 634, 235 S.E.2d at 720.Â  
The trial court found that Red Oak failed to state 
  facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  Id. at 632-633, 235 
  S.E.2d at 719.Â  On appeal, Red Oak argued, among other things, that the trial 
  court erred in refusing to grant its request to replead.Â  Specifically, Red 
  Oak wanted to amend its complaint to include a common law action for the tax 
  collectorâ€™s misfeasance related to the sale.Â  The supreme court found the statutory 
  remedy provided to tax sale purchasers was exclusive, and therefore â€œit would 
  be a futile gesture to grant Red Oak the right to repleadâ€ because the two-year 
  limitation period provided by Section 65-2785 had expired.Â  Id. at 636, 
  235 S.E.2d at 720. 
The Red Oak Lands court held that the exclusive 
  remedy for recovery of the purchase price of a tax sale was the remedy provided 
  by statute.Â  However, unlike Red Oaks, the bidders in this case are not attempting 
  to assert a common law cause of action against the County for recovery of the 
  purchase price in addition to the cause of action provided by statute. 
  Instead, the bidders acknowledge that their only relief stems from section 12-51-150.Â  
  However, they argue that because section 12-51-150 is silent regarding which 
  party is entitled to the interest, we should consider the rules of equity when 
  interpreting the statute and find that the statuteâ€™s requirement that the County 
  return the bid price implicitly directs the County to return actual interest 
  earned as well.Â  We agree.
Equity is reserved for situations when there is 
  no adequate remedy at law.Â  Santee Cooper Resort, Inc. v. South Carolina 
  Pub. Serv. Comm'n, 298 S.C. 179, 185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989).Â  
  For a court to justify refusing to exercise equity, the remedy at law must be 
  adequate.Â  Chisolm v. Pryor, 207 S.C. 54, 60, 35 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1945).Â  
  Furthermore, â€œ[i]t is not enough that there is some remedy at law, but that 
  remedy must be as practical, efficient, and prompt as the remedy in equity.â€Â  
  Id.  
In this case, no adequate legal remedy exists.Â  Section 
  12-51-150 requires the return of the purchase price, but is silent as to any 
  interest earned.Â  Without resorting to equitable remedies, no remedy exists 
  to prevent the County from reaping a benefit from its own mistakes.Â  
The County argues that, pursuant to Santee Cooper 
  Resort, Inc. v. South Carolina Public Service Commission, 298 S.C. 179, 
  185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989),Â  â€œ[t]he courtâ€™s equitable powers must 
  yield in the face of an unambiguously worded statute.â€Â  However, in Santee 
  Cooper Resort, Inc., the supreme court found an adequate legal remedy existed 
  when it was confronted by clear â€œstatutory alternatives adequately enabl[ing] 
  the Consumer Advocate to achieve the goal of consumer protection.â€Â  Id.Â  
  This is in sharp contrast to the case at hand.Â  Here, the statute contains no 
  statutory provision addressing the issue of interest, and without resorting 
  to equity, no remedy would exist.Â  It is an equitable maxim that â€œ[e]quity will 
  not suffer a wrong without a remedy.â€Â  Lane v. New York Life Ins. Co., 147 
  S.C. 333, 369, 145 S.E. 196, 207 (1928); see also State ex rel. 
  Daniel v. Strong, 185 S.C. 27, 43, 192 S.E. 671, 678 (1937) (â€œ[E]quity abhors 
  a wrong without a remedy.â€).Â  Where, as here, a wrong has been suffered, and 
  no adequate legal remedy exists, it is well within the courtâ€™s powers to fashion 
  an equitable remedy. 
In this case, the master-in-equity used the equitable 
  remedy of restitution to disgorge from the County the interest it earned on 
  the biddersâ€™ money.Â  In order to recover under a theory of restitution, the 
  bidders must show: (1) they conferred a non-gratuitous benefit on the County; 
  (2) the County realized some value from the benefit; and (3) it would be inequitable 
  for the County to retain the benefit without paying the bidders for its value.Â  
  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 409, 581 
  S.E.2d 161, 167 (2003).
In the case at hand, the bidders clearly meet the 
  first two elements of restitution: (1) the bidders paid for real property expecting 
  to gain title; and (2) the County received $28,010.93 in interest while holding 
  the biddersâ€™ money.Â  As to the third element, the County argues that no inequity 
  occurred because a clear and disclosed term of the tax sale was that, in the 
  event the sale was voided, the bidder would not receive interest on the bid 
  price.Â Â Â  Importantly, however, the County never argued that this notice estops 
  the bidders from claiming that they are entitled to interest.Â  Furthermore, 
  we do not believe that the bidders should be precluded from pursuing their equitable 
  entitlement to interest merely because the County, apparently relying on section 
  12-51-150â€™s silence, notified bidders that no interest would be awarded in the 
  event the sale was voided.
Balancing all the equities, we find that, in spite 
  of the Countyâ€™s notice to bidders, it would be unjust to allow the County to 
  keep the interest on the purchase prices of tax sales that were voided due to 
  the Countyâ€™s own errors and omissions.Â  To reward the County for its own internal 
  errors would discourage the County from carefully conducting tax sales.Â  Further, 
  because the amount of interest earned is determined in part by the amount of 
  time the County retains a bidderâ€™s purchase price, the County would have little 
  incentive to promptly return the bidderâ€™s money after a tax sale is voided.Â Â  
  Thus, equity dictates that bidders, not the County, are entitled to the interest 
  their money actually earns while in the possession of the County when a tax 
  sale is voided.
Accordingly, the master-in-equityâ€™s decision to award $28,010.93 
  in restitution is 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charlotte O'Braitis,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Catheryne Ruth O'Braitis,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph  M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No.Â  3858Â 
Heard June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed August 16, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Clinch H. Belser, Jr. and Michael J. Polk, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Demetri K. Koutrakos, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Â Â Â  Charlotte Oâ€™Braitis brought 
  this action seeking the partition of real property and an accounting for rents 
  and profits against her sister, Catheryne Ruth Oâ€™Braitis, alleging Catheryne 
  ousted her from a piece of real property the two parties own.Â  Charlotte appeals 
  the trial courtâ€™s order granting the partition but denying her request for expenses 
  and rents caused by Catheryneâ€™s alleged ouster.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Charlotte and Catheryneâ€™s father 
  passed away on April 19, 1997, and left his home to his four children in equal 
  shares.Â  Two of the siblings gave their share of the property to Catheryne, 
  who had lived in the home assisting her father since 1983.Â  Charlotte, who resides 
  in California, retained her one-quarter share of the property.Â Â Â Â Â  
Upon learning of her fatherâ€™s death, Charlotte 
  and her domestic partner, Dr. Weissman, visited the subject property for the 
  first time since 1983.Â  The day after her fatherâ€™s funeral, Charlotte and Dr. 
  Weissman began going through the home in order to find Charlotteâ€™s personal 
  belongings.Â  While they attempted to find her things, Charlotte testified that 
  her siblings hovered over her and that her brother became verbally abusive and 
  confrontational.Â  Because of her brotherâ€™s behavior, Charlotte called the sheriffâ€™s 
  office.Â  The officer, acting on his own volition and without any instruction 
  from Catheryne, ordered Charlotte and Dr. Weissman off of the property and issued 
  a trespassing warrant under which Charlotte and Dr. Weissman were not allowed 
  on the property for six months.
Approximately one year later, Charlotte and Dr. 
  Weissman visited the property for the purpose of reviewing personal property 
  of her fatherâ€™s estate. Charlotte testified that Catheryne did not welcome her 
  on the property; however, the evidence shows that Catheryne did not deny Charlotte 
  access to the property. [1] Â Â  

In September 1998, Charlotte and Dr. Weissman returned 
  to the property again for the purpose of reviewing personal property of the 
  estate.Â  During this visit, Catheryne hired a Richland County police officer 
  to keep things under control.Â  The officer testified that Charlotte walked into 
  the house without knocking and went through the personal property without supervision.Â Â  

In April 1999, Charlotte filed an action against 
  her siblings in probate court, seeking an accounting, termination of the appointment 
  of the personal representative, and other relief.Â  In the probate action, Charlotte 
  alleged Catheryne interfered with and obstructed her right to enter the subject 
  property and sought to recoup money she spent on attorneyâ€™s fees and other expenses 
  incurred during the probate of her fatherâ€™s estate.Â  The parties later entered 
  into an agreement pursuant to section 62-3-912 of the South Carolina code, and 
  the probate court action was then dismissed with prejudice on June 1, 2000, 
  pursuant to an order of dismissal to which all parties consented. 
On August 4, 2000, Charlotte brought this action 
  for a partition and an accounting of rents and profits based on Catheryneâ€™s 
  ouster of her from the property.Â  Catheryne asserted counterclaims for partition 
  and accounting and alleged Charlotteâ€™s claims were barred by res judicata.Â  
  The case was referred to the master-in-equity.Â  The master issued an order granting 
  partition, denying compensation for ouster, and allowing Catheryne to purchase 
  Charlotteâ€™s portion of the property for the net price (after offsets) of $2,264.31. 
  Â Charlotte filed a motion to reconsider, which the master denied.Â  This 
  appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A partition action, as well as an action 
  for accounting, is an action in equity.Â  In an appeal from an equitable action, 
  this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of 
  the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Doe v. Clark, 318 S.C. 274, 276, 
  457 S.E.2d 336, 337 (1995).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require 
  this court to disregard the findings at trial or ignore the fact that the trial 
  judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  
  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 
  477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.      
Ouster 
Charlotte first argues the master erred in finding 
  that Catheryne was not obligated to pay the expenses she incurred and the rent 
  that she lost during the time she was allegedly ousted from the property.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  
â€œâ€˜Ousterâ€™ is the actual turning out or keeping 
  excluded a party entitled to possession of any real property.â€Â  Freeman v. 
  Freeman, 323 S.C. 95, 99, 473 S.E.2d 467, 470 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œBy actual 
  ouster is not meant a physical eviction, but a possession attended with such 
  circumstances as to evince a claim of exclusive right and title and a denial 
  of the right of the other tenants to participate in the profits.â€Â  Woods 
  v. Bivens, 292 S.C. 76, 80, 354 S.E.2d 909, 912 (1987).Â  Freeman 
  provides:

The acts relied upon to establish an ouster must be of an 
  unequivocal nature, and so distinctly hostile to the rights of the other cotenants 
  that the intention to disseize is clear and unmistakable.Â  Only in rare, extreme 
  cases will the ouster by one cotenant of other cotenants be implied from exclusive 
  possession and dealings with the property, such as collection of rents and improvement 
  of the property.Â Â  

323 S.C. at 99, 473 S.E.2d at 470 (citation omitted).Â  

Charlotte argues that Catheryne ousted her from 
  the property by (1) refusing to give her a key to the property; [2]  (2) not allowing her unfettered access to the 
  property; and (3) acquiescing in the trespass warrant issued by the police officer.Â  
  Charlotte contends these actions closely resemble those of the defendant in 
  Parker v. Shecut, 349 S.C. 226, 562 S.E.2d 620 (2002).Â  In Parker, 
  a sister brought suit against her brother alleging he ousted her from a beach 
  house they inherited jointly from their mother.Â  The supreme court found an 
  ouster had occurred based on evidence that the brother changed the locks to 
  the house, refused to give his sister a working key, and otherwise denied his 
  sister access to the property.Â  Id. at 230-31, 562 S.E.2d at 623.Â  
We find the present case differs significantly 
  from Parker. It is uncontested that Catheryne allowed Charlotte access 
  to the property every time she visited.Â  In fact, on all three of Charlotteâ€™s 
  visits to the property, she and Dr. Weissman walked freely through the house, 
  looking at and going through personal property.Â  According to the police officer, 
  when Charlotte and Dr. Weissman arrived for the September 1998 visit, â€œ[t]hey 
  came to the front door, just walked straight on in, no knock at all, whatsoever.â€Â  
  The officer also stated they â€œwent around the house by themselvesâ€ and â€œwere 
  going through every bit of the property.â€Â  This is hardly a denial of access 
  to the property. 
Furthermore, any acquiescence by Catheryne in 
  the trespass warrant of April 1997 is not enough to support a finding of ouster.Â  
  It is important to note that Charlotte, not Catheryne, was the one who called 
  an officer to the scene when the altercation ensued between Charlotte and her 
  siblings.Â  Because Charlotte enlisted the help of an outside party to settle 
  the dispute, she cannot now attribute the effect of the trespass warrant to 
  Catheryne.Â  Based on all the above, we find Catheryneâ€™s actions toward Charlotte 
  do not amount to ouster.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Not only do we hold no ouster occurred, 
  we also hold Charlotteâ€™s claim for an accounting is barred by res judicata, 
  or more specifically, issue preclusion.Â  Under the doctrine of issue preclusion, 
  if an issue of fact or law was actually litigated and determined and necessary 
  to a valid and final judgment, the determination is conclusive in a subsequent 
  action on that claim or a different claim.Â  Carman v. S.C. Alcoholic Beverage 
  Control Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 1, 6, 451 S.E.2d 383, 386 (1994).Â  
Here, Charlotte filed a petition in probate court 
  seeking an accounting for the attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses she incurred while 
  traveling between California and South Carolina.Â  Charlotte also alleged in 
  the probate court action that she was entitled to rent from Catheryne because 
  Catheryne interfered with her right to enter the property. Â Thus, in the probate 
  court action, just as in the present action, Charlotte sought the expenses she 
  incurred and the rent she lost during the time she was allegedly denied access 
  to the property.Â  In fact, Charlotte even admitted while testifying in the present 
  action that she had filed a complaint against Catheryne in probate court raising 
  the same issues that she raises in this action. 
The probate court dismissed the action with prejudice 
  pursuant to an order of dismissal to which the parties consented.Â  A dismissal 
  with prejudice acts as an adjudication on the merits and therefore precludes 
  subsequent litigation just as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.Â  
  Jones v. City of Folly Beach, 326 S.C. 360, 366, 483 S.E.2d 770, 773 
  (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In a subsequent action involving the same subject matter, 
  the dismissal finally settles all matters litigated in the earlier proceedings, 
  and all matters which might have been litigated therein.Â  Nunnery v. Brantley 
  Constr. Co, 289 S.C. 205, 209, 345 S.E.2d 740, 743 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Because 
  Charlotte raised the same issue in the probate action and that issue was necessary 
  to and determined in an adjudication on the merits, she is precluded from raising 
  the issue again in this action.Â  
Charlotte attempts to make a distinction between 
  the issues raised to the probate court and the trial court by arguing that, 
  in the probate court action, she sought access to the subject property for 
  the purpose of inspecting the personal property only because that is the only 
  relief available in Probate Court. Â We find this argument unconvincing.Â  


It is a fundamental principle of jurisprudence that material 
  facts or questions which were directly in issue in a former action, and were 
  there admitted or judicially determined, are conclusively settled by a judgment 
  rendered therein, and that such facts or questions become res judicata 
  and may not again be litigated in a subsequent action between the same parties 
  or their privies, regardless of the form that the issue may take in the subsequent 
  action.Â  
. . .
The rule will also apply even though the subsequent action 
  is upon a different cause of action, and involves a different subject matter, 
  claim, or demand, than the earlier action.Â  In such cases, it is likewise 
  immaterial that the two actions have a different scope, or are 
  based on different grounds, or are tried on different theories, 
  or are instituted for different purposes, and seek different relief.

46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments Â§ 539 (1994) (emphasis 
  added).Â Â  
Therefore, Charlotteâ€™s argument that, in the probate 
  action, she only sought access to the property for the purpose of inspecting 
  personal property is not enough to allow her present claim for ouster to go 
  forward.Â  In addition, this distinction fails because Charlotte testified that 
  all her visits to the property were for the purpose of inspecting personal property.Â  
  She cannot now claim that she wanted access to the property for any other reason 
  than to inspect the personal property of her fatherâ€™s estate.Â  It is clear that 
  she raised the same issue in both the probate court and the trial court.Â  Therefore, 
  Charlotteâ€™s claim that she is due an accounting based on Catheryneâ€™s ouster 
  is barred by res judicata.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Trial Courtâ€™s Calculation of the Net Price 
  for Charlotteâ€™s Share of the PropertyÂ  
Charlotte next argues the trial court incorrectly 
  calculated the net price Catheryne should pay for Charlotteâ€™s share of the property 
  by crediting Catheryne for the amount the property increased in value due to 
  Catheryneâ€™s improvements to the property.Â  We find the trial court correctly 
  determined the net price.Â  
Catheryne spent approximately $9,859.80 in making 
  improvements to the property, such as renovating the living room, dining room, 
  and the kitchen.Â  Catheryne testified that due to the improvements, the property 
  increased in value from $53,000 to $55,000.Â  Charlotte argues Catheryne should 
  not receive credit for the $2,000 increase because Catheryne made these improvements 
  unilaterally, and thus, at her own risk.Â  It is immaterial that Catheryne made 
  these improvements without Charlotteâ€™s consent.Â  As our court explained in Ackerman 
  v. Heard: 

The general rule is that a joint tenant who, at his own expense, 
  places permanent improvements upon the common property is entitled in a partition 
  suit to compensation for the improvements whether his cotenants assented thereto 
  or not.Â  Compensation is allowed not as a matter of legal right but purely from 
  the desire of a court of equity to do justice and to prevent the one tenant 
  from becoming enriched at the expense of another.Â  In the absence of consent, 
  which we did not have in the case before us, the amount of compensation is estimated 
  by and limited to the amount by which the value of the common property 
  has been enhanced.Â  

287 S.C. 626, 628-29, 340 S.E.2d 560, 562 (Ct. 
  App. 1986) (emphasis in original).Â  Because the improvements to the property 
  increased the value of the property by $2,000, the trial court properly gave 
  Catheryne $2,000 in credit.Â  While we agree with the trial judgeâ€™s decision 
  to reimburse Catheryne for the improvements to the property, we point out a 
  clarification in the amount Catheryne must pay Charlotte.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s 
  order misstated the amount of increase in value to be $2,500, but his later 
  order denying Charlotteâ€™s motion to reconsider corrected the error.Â  However, 
  the trial court did not specifically correct the net price to be paid to Catheryne 
  based on an increase in value of $2,000.Â  To clarify this issue for the parties, 
  we find that Catheryne must pay Charlotte $2,764.31 for her share of the property 
  based on an increase in the fair market value of the property of $2,000, and 
  taking into consideration the trial courtâ€™s calculations for taxes, insurance, 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees.
III.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
 Charlotte claims the trial court erred 
  in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Catheryne because Charlotte was required to bring 
  this action based on Catheryneâ€™s ouster.Â  We disagree.Â  
The determination of whether to award attorneyâ€™s 
  fees in partition actions rests within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  
  S&W Corp. of Inman v. Wells, 283 S.C. 218, 220, 321 S.E.2d 183, 185 
  (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The trial court may â€œfix attorneysâ€™ fees in all partition 
  proceedings and, as may be equitable, assess such fees against any or all of 
  the parties in interest.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-61-110 (Supp. 1976).
Although Charlotte argues she was required to 
  bring this partition action because of Catheryneâ€™s ouster, as discussed above, 
  no ouster occurred.Â  Moreover, Catheryne was forced to defend allegations that 
  were previously raised and dismissed with prejudice in the probate court action.Â  
  Based on the above, and giving deference to the trial court, we find the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees was proper.
CONCLUSION  
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  Certain incidents did occur, 
    however, which made Charlotte feel threatened.Â  For instance, Charlotte and 
    Catheryneâ€™s brother â€œgoose-steppedâ€ around the outside of the house with a 
    pellet gun slung over his shoulder and a Nazi flag on his back in front of 
    Dr. Weissman, who is Jewish. 

 
   
    [2]  Charlotte claims she repeatedly requested a key to the house after 
    her fatherâ€™s death in 1997, but Catheryne never gave her one.Â  Catheryne explained 
    that she did not give Charlotte a key because the estate had not yet been 
    settled and every time Charlotte was in the house something was broken.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Stark Truss Co., Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Superior Construction Corporation and National Fire Insurance Company 
        of Hartford,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3859
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed August 
  16, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
A. Cruickshanks, IV, of Clinton; and Steele B. Windle, 
  III, of Charlotte, for Appellants.
Paul B. Zion, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Superior Construction Corporation 
  and National Fire Insurance Company of Hartford (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€) 
  appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order denying their motion to set aside an entry 
  of default judgment and dismissing their counterclaims against Stark Truss Co., 
  Inc.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part and remand.
FACTS
In 2001, Superior signed a purchase 
  order agreement under which Stark Truss was to manufacture and deliver all the 
  roof trusses Superior needed to complete a school construction project for the 
  amount of $95,861. Â National issued Superior a labor and materials payment 
  bond on the project. Â A dispute arose between Superior and Stark Truss 
  concerning the condition of the trusses provided.Â  Superior refused to pay in 
  full for the materials, and Stark Truss refused to deliver the remaining materials 
  without full payment. Â Superior obtained replacement materials from another 
  supplier. Â In June 2002, Stark Truss filed a $49,799 payment bond claim 
  with National for the remaining balance of the purchase order price.Â  National 
  denied Stark Trussâ€™s claim on the basis of the existence of a bona fide dispute. 

On July 12, 2002, Stark Truss filed 
  a summons and complaint against Appellants for the remaining balance plus interest. 
  Â The summons and complaint were served upon Superior on July 24 and upon 
  National on July 26. Â National gave its defense in the matter to Superior 
  on August 5, 2002, apparently intending for Superior to answer on its behalf.Â  

Superior did not send a copy of 
  Stark Trussâ€™s summons and complaint or Nationalâ€™s suit papers to its attorneys 
  until September 5, 2002.Â  Upon receipt that same morning, Appellantsâ€™ attorneys 
  immediately telephoned Stark Trussâ€™s attorneys and requested an extension of 
  time in which to file an answer. Â Later that day, Appellantsâ€™ attorneys 
  were contacted by one of Stark Trussâ€™s attorneys and informed that default proceedings 
  had already begun, with the motion for entry of default judgment and affidavit 
  of default being mailed that morning prior to the initial call.Â  Stark Truss 
  denied the request for an extension. Â Â 
The Appellantsâ€™ joint answer and counterclaim for 
  damages in excess of $75,000 was prepared, filed with the court on September 
  6, 2002, and served on Stark Truss.Â  Stark Trussâ€™s affidavit of default, motion 
  for entry of default judgment, and a proposed order directing entry of default 
  judgment, dated September 5, 2002, were received and filed five days later on 
  September 11, 2002. Â Based on Stark Trussâ€™s motion, the court issued 
  an order, without a hearing, simultaneously granting entry of default and a 
  default judgment against Appellants. 
On September 12, Stark Truss served on 
  Appellantsâ€™ attorneys its motion to dismiss Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims, asserting 
  the compulsory claims were barred by the default judgment.Â  Appellants filed 
  a â€œMotion to Set Aside Entry of Default Judgmentâ€ on October 22, 2002, in which 
  Appellants argued both the entry of default and default judgment should be set 
  aside.Â  At the motions hearing, Appellants argued that because they filed an 
  answer and counterclaim prior to the courtâ€™s receipt of the motion for entry 
  of default and default judgment, they had appeared in the matter, rendering 
  the facts supporting the motion for default judgment inaccurate.Â  Appellants 
  also asserted that because they had appeared, entry of default was improper 
  and required the entry of default judgment to be set aside.Â  Appellantsâ€™ attorney 
  informed the circuit court that there was no good explanation for not filing 
  an answer within thirty days, other than the fact that Superiorâ€™s president 
  was â€œstruggling with some depression and a lot of things slipped through his 
  fingers.â€Â Â  
On November 15, 2002, the circuit 
  court issued an order holding that Appellants had failed to present sufficient 
  proof of either â€œgood causeâ€ for relief from default under Rule 55(c), SCRCP, 
  or â€œmistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglectâ€ under Rule 60(b), 
  SCRCP sufficient to vacate the entry of default judgment.Â  Since the counterclaims 
  were compulsory and the answer was not timely filed, the court also granted 
  Stark Trussâ€™s motion to dismiss all counterclaims.Â  Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision whether to set aside an entry 
  of default or a default judgment lies solely within the sound discretion of 
  the trial judge.Â  Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 
  900, 902-903 (1989); Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 
  465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 502 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  This decision will not be reversed 
  absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Thompson, 299 S.C. at 119, 382 S.E.2d 
  at 902-903; In Re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 259, 495 S.E.2d 454, 
  459 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the order was controlled 
  by an error of law or when the order is without evidentiary support.Â  Id. 
  Â Â 
LAW / ANALYSIS
A.
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in entering 
  default and in refusing to set aside the entry of default because they appeared 
  in the matter by filing their answer and counterclaim prior to the filing of 
  the motion for entry of default.Â  We disagree.Â  
A determination in this case requires an evaluation 
  of Rule 55, SCRCP regarding default judgments.Â  When interpreting a court rule, 
  â€œwe apply the same rules of construction used in interpreting statutes.Â  Therefore, 
  the words of [the rule] must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without 
  resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the rule.â€Â  Green 
  v. Lewis Truck Lines, Inc., 314 S.C. 303, 304, 443 S.E.2d 906, 907 (1994).Â  
  When the language of a court rule is clear and unambiguous, the court is obligated 
  to follow its plain and ordinary meaning.Â  
Unless an extension is granted, a defendant must 
  serve his answer within thirty days â€œafter the service of the complaint upon 
  him.â€Â  Rule 12(a), SCRCP.Â  If a party has failed to â€œplead or otherwise defend [1]  as provided by [the South Carolina 
  Rules of Civil Procedure] and that fact is made to appear by affidavit or otherwise,â€ 
  the clerk of court will enter default.Â  Rule 55(a), SCRCP.Â  Entry of default 
  is a ministerial act which a clerk is required to perform once default is made 
  to appear by the affidavit of the moving party.Â  See Thynes v. Lloyd, 
  294 S.C. 152, 153-54, 363 S.E.2d 122, 123 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding that â€œwhether 
  default was actually entered is of no consequence since the entry of default 
  is a purely ministerial act which the clerk was required to perform once the 
  default was made to appear by the affidavitâ€ of the moving party).Â  
Appellants initially argue the circuit court erred in entering 
  default.Â  Although Appellantsâ€™ late answer amounted to a â€œpleadingâ€ filed prior 
  to entry of default, it did not comply with the time requirements of Rule 12(a), 
  SCRCP.Â  Appellants clearly failed to file an answer within thirty days of service 
  of the summons and complaint upon them and they were technically in default.Â  
  Thus, Appellantsâ€™ answer was not a valid pleading or defense â€œas provided byâ€ 
  the Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  A plain reading of Rule 55(a) allows entry of 
  default when a pleading or defense is asserted in a manner noncompliant with 
  the Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  To hold otherwise would render the requirements 
  in Rule 12(a), SCRCP, meaningless.Â  We find the courtâ€™s entry of default was 
  proper.
Appellants point to cases from other jurisdictions holding 
  that entry of default is improper if even a late answer is filed prior to entry 
  of default.Â  See, e.g., Moore v. Sullivan, 473 S.E.2d 659, 
  660 (N.C. Ct. App. 1996) (â€œAfter an answer has been filed, even if the answer 
  is untimely filed, a default may not be entered.â€).Â  That is not the current 
  law in this state.Â  Further, filing a late answer would not alter the fact that 
  Appellants were in default, especially if entering default is a ministerial 
  act to be automatically performed once an affidavit shows the defendant has 
  failed to comply with the requirements of the rules.Â  Thynes, 294 S.C. 
  at 153-54, 363 S.E.2d at 123.Â  
Appellants also argue the circuit court erred in 
  denying their motion to set aside the entry of default.Â  We disagree.
Rule 55(c), SCRCP, allows the circuit court to 
  set aside an entry of default â€œfor good cause shown.â€Â  Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œIn 
  deciding whether good cause exists, the trial court should consider the following 
  factors: (1) the timing of the defendantâ€™s motion for relief; (2) whether the 
  defendant has a meritorious defense; and (3) the degree of prejudice to the 
  plaintiff if relief is granted.â€Â  Pilgrim v. Miller, 350 S.C. 637, 640, 
  567 S.E.2d 527, 528 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. dismissed (April 25, 2003).Â  
  Whether to grant relief from entry of default is a decision within the sound 
  discretion of the circuit court.Â  Wham, 298 S.C. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 
  502.Â  In reviewing the courtâ€™s exercise of discretion, the issue before the 
  appellate court is not whether it believes good cause existed to set aside the 
  default, â€œbut rather, whether the [trial judgeâ€™s] determination is supportable 
  by the evidence and not controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Pilgrim, 350 
  S.C. at 640-41, 567 S.E.2d at 528.Â  
Appellantsâ€™ motion for relief from entry of default 
  was filed over a month after the circuit court entered default judgment.Â  They 
  argued that the entry of default should be set aside because they appeared prior 
  to entry of default.Â  The attorney for Appellants informed the circuit court 
  that Superiorâ€™s president had no good reason, other than depression, for failing 
  to act when he was served with the summons and complaint.Â  The attorney did 
  not give any reason for Nationalâ€™s failure to serve and file its answer to the 
  summons and complaint.Â  Based on these facts, we find there was evidence to 
  support the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to set aside the entry of default.Â Â Â  
B.
Appellants argue that because they filed a late 
  answer, they made an â€œappearanceâ€ in the action and entry of default judgment 
  was improper.Â  They further argue that the circuit court erred in refusing to 
  set aside the default judgment.Â  We agree.
Rule 55(b)(1), SCRCP, entitled â€œCases Involving Liquidated 
  Damages or Sum Certain,â€ provides that where the amount sought is a sum certain 
  and the defaulting party has not made an appearance, the judge may enter 
  default judgment for the amount sought without holding a hearing.Â  Rule 55(b)(2), 
  entitled â€œAll Other Cases,â€ provides, in pertinent part, that a party who has 
  â€œappearedâ€ in the action is entitled to notice and a hearing before judgment 
  by default may be entered.Â  A party may seek relief from a default judgment 
  for mistake, inadvertence, newly discovered evidence, fraud or other misconduct, 
  where the judgment is void, or where the judgment has been satisfied.Â  Rule 
  60(b), SCRCP.Â Â  
Whether Appellantsâ€™ late answer amounted to an 
  â€œappearanceâ€ in this case is a critical question.Â  This court has previously 
  discussed whether a late filing constitutes an â€œappearance.â€Â  In Dymon v. 
  Hyman, 305 S.C. 170, 406 S.E.2d 388 (Ct. App. 1991), the defendant filed 
  and served his answer late, and the plaintiff acknowledged service of the late 
  answer.Â  However, the plaintiff informed the defendant that he considered the 
  defendant to be in default.Â  Two months later, the plaintiff sought and obtained 
  a judgment by default without giving notice to the defendant.Â  The defendant 
  learned of the default judgment months later, and the circuit court denied the 
  motion for relief from judgment.Â  Interpreting the prior version of Rule 55(b)(1), [2]  this court held that the defendantâ€™s late answer 
  was an â€œappearanceâ€ and thus the defendant was entitled to notice and a hearing 
  on the motion for default judgment.Â  Because no notice was given, this court 
  reversed the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to set aside the void judgment.Â  Dymon, 
  305 S.C. at 171, 406 S.E.2d at 389.Â  
Appellants in the present case clearly filed their answer 
  and counterclaims more than thirty days after they were served with the summons 
  and complaint.Â  However, as in Dymon, Appellantsâ€™ late answer, filed 
  before Stark Trussâ€™s motions were received by the circuit court, constituted 
  an appearance in the matter.Â  Appellants were entitled to notice and a hearing 
  before judgment by default was entered.Â  Dymon, 305 S.C. at 171-72, 406 
  S.E.2d at 389.Â  Because no notice was given and no hearing was held, the default 
  judgment was void.Â  The circuit court erred in refusing to relieve Appellants 
  from the void judgment.Â  Id.; see also Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP (â€œOn 
  motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his 
  legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding [where] . . 
  . the judgment is void.â€).
C.
Appellants assert the circuit court erred in granting 
  Stark Trussâ€™s motion to dismiss their counterclaims as compulsory.Â  We disagree.Â  

The circuit court found, and Appellants do not 
  dispute, that the counterclaims asserted with the late answer were compulsory.Â  
  Rule 13(a), SCRCP, provides that compulsory counterclaims must be asserted along 
  with a responsive pleading.Â  As Appellants were in default and failed to timely 
  file and serve their answer, they also failed to timely assert their counterclaims.Â  
  In this instance, we find the circuit court did not err in dismissing the Appellantsâ€™ 
  counterclaims.Â  
CONCLUSION
Appellants failed to timely serve and file their answer and 
  compulsory counterclaims on Stark Truss pursuant to the Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  
  Thus, the entry of default was proper, the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to set aside 
  the entry of default was supported by the evidence, and the dismissal of Appellantsâ€™ 
  compulsory counterclaims was proper.Â  However, as Appellants made an appearance 
  in this action by filing a late answer, they were entitled to notice before 
  entry of default judgment.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s refusal to set aside the void 
  default judgment was error.Â  We reverse the refusal to set aside the default 
  judgment and remand for proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court 
  is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  â€œThe words â€˜otherwise defendâ€™ refer to the interposition of various 
    challenges to such matters as service, venue, and the sufficiency of the prior 
    pleading, any of which might prevent a default if pursued in the absence of 
    a responsive pleading.â€Â  10A Charles Allen Wright, Arthur R. Miller & 
    Mary Kay Kane, Federal Practice and Procedure Â§ 2682, at 16-17 (3rd 
    ed. 1989).Â  

 
   
    [2]  The prior version of Rule 55(b)(1) is nearly identical to the current 
    version of Rule 55(b)(2).Â  The rules were amended in 1998 to add the version 
    of Rule 55(b)(1) concerning default judgments with liquidated damages and 
    where the defaulting party has failed to appear.Â  The former Rule 55(b)(1) 
    became Rule 55(b)(2).Â  See Rule 55, SCRCP Notes to 1998 Amendments.Â Â Â
