title: State v. Lee
description: Appellant appeals his convictions for four counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and one count of lewd act upon a child.  Appellant asserts the State violated his Fifth Amendment guarantee of due process of law through excessive pre-indictment delay.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Larry Lee, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
  Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3860
  Heard May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed August 23, 2004

VACATED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and 
          Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Larry Lee appeals his convictions for four counts of 
  first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and one count of lewd 
  act upon a child.Â  Lee asserts the State violated his Fifth Amendment guarantee 
  of due process of law through excessive pre-indictment delay. [1] Â  For the reasons set forth below, we vacate 
  Leeâ€™s convictions.
FACTS 
Diana Baldwin married Larry Lee on August 29, 1982.Â  After they married, Diana, 
  Lee, Dianaâ€™s two daughters, who were six and seven years old, and her one-year-old 
  son moved into a home in Aiken.Â  In the latter part of 1988, the Department 
  of Social Services (DSS) began an investigation when Leeâ€™s stepdaughters alleged 
  that he had sexually abused them.Â  The allegations of abuse first arose during 
  a juvenile criminal investigation being conducted against the stepdaughters 
  by law enforcement officers.Â  As a result of the investigation, DSS removed 
  the girls from the home on September 15, 1988, and placed them in the custody 
  of their aunt on an emergency basis until a hearing could be held in the family 
  court.Â  Within two to three months, DSS returned the girls to their home.Â  Diana 
  and Lee ultimately divorced in September of 1992. 
Though the solicitorâ€™s office represented the State during all hearings before 
  the family court, the State took no further action on the matter for more than 
  twelve years after the childrenâ€™s return home.Â  On May 14, 2001, an Aiken County 
  grand jury indicted Lee for four counts of first-degree CSC with a minor and 
  one count of lewd act upon a child, all arising from the allegations involving 
  the stepdaughters.Â  Around this same time, Lee was indicted for additional counts 
  of CSC with a minor for incidents that occurred with different victims, including 
  a niece, between 1985 and 1988 and in 1999. 
  [2] 
On May 17-21, 2001, Lee was tried only on the indictments involving the stepdaughters.Â  
  Based on the delay, Leeâ€™s counsel requested at the pre-trial hearing that the 
  court dismiss these indictments.Â  During the pre-trial hearing, Leeâ€™s counsel 
  informed the judge the State was aware of the charges in 1988 but did not arrest 
  Lee until March 2001 and did not indict him until May 2001.Â  According to Leeâ€™s 
  counsel, the DSS worker who was involved in the case wrote a letter on January 
  6, 1989, stating DSS â€œbelieved there was criminal activityâ€ and requested law 
  enforcement make an investigation into the criminal matter.Â  Leeâ€™s counsel also 
  stated she was unable to locate records to determine whether this investigation 
  had taken place.Â  Because the State was aware of potential criminal charges 
  against Lee in 1988 and did not bring them until the 1999 charges involving 
  Leeâ€™s niece, counsel argued the charges involving the stepdaughters should be 
  dismissed.Â  She contended Lee suffered substantial prejudice as a result of 
  the Stateâ€™s â€œnegligentâ€ delay in bringing the charges.Â  She claimed Lee was 
  prejudiced due to the destruction of crucial records, the absence of witnesses, 
  and the witnessesâ€™ inability to recall the alleged incidents in detail.Â Â  
Specifically, counsel pointed out that the subject 
  matter of the original investigation against the stepdaughters could not be 
  determined given the DSS file had been destroyed and the juvenile officer who 
  originally reported the matter to DSS recalled no details of the investigation.Â  
  In similar fashion, the stepdaughtersâ€™ school records were no longer available.Â  
  In addition, the attorney that originally represented Lee before the family 
  court no longer practiced law in South Carolina and could not be located.Â  Based 
  on these hindrances, Leeâ€™s counsel moved for the trial judge to dismiss the 
  indictments because the delay in indicting Lee had affected his ability to mount 
  an adequate defense.Â  Though the State offered no explanation for the delay 
  of more than twelve years, it countered that Lee offered no evidence the State 
  intentionally delayed prosecution of the charges. 
At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge denied 
  Leeâ€™s speedy trial motion, but stated there â€œmay be a 5th Amendment right for 
  pre-indictment or pre-arrest matter, but the law seems to indicate that one, 
  there has to beâ€”show prejudice and two you have to show intention on the part 
  of the government to try and . . . put the individual in a worse position.â€ 
  Â The judge then denied the motion.
The day of the trial, Leeâ€™s counsel renewed her 
  motion.Â  She argued Leeâ€™s right to a fair trial had been compromised by the 
  â€œexcessive delay on the part of the State.â€Â  The judge again denied the motion, 
  stating â€œthe 6th Amendment, the right begins at the time of arrest or indictment 
  and if youâ€™re alleging on the 5th Amendment, then youâ€™ve got to show prejudice 
  . . . and you also got to show there was some intent on the part of the State 
  to put you in a position, a disadvantage.â€  
  [3]  
The jury convicted Lee of four counts of first-degree 
  CSC with a minor and one count of lewd act upon a child.Â  The judge sentenced 
  Lee to an aggregate of forty-five years imprisonment.Â  Lee appeals his convictions 
  and sentences.
DISCUSSION
Lee argues his convictions should be vacated because of the excessive pre-indictment 
  delay.Â  We agree.
â€œThe Due Process Clause plays a limited role in protecting against oppressive 
  pre-indictment delay.â€ State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 72, 480 S.E.2d 
  64, 68 (1997); see United States v. Lovasco, 431 U.S. 783, 789-90 
  (1977) (analyzing Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment with respect to 
  pre-indictment delay); United States v. Marion, 404 U.S. 307, 324 (1971) 
  (recognizing Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment provides basis for dismissing 
  indictment as a result of pre-indictment delay). 
In Brazell, our supreme court considered 
  the issue of pre-indictment delay.Â  In its analysis, the court relied on decisions 
  of the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.Â  The court stated:Â  

  The United States Supreme Court has developed a two-prong inquiry when pre-indictment 
    delay is alleged to violate due process.Â  First, the defendant has the burden 
    of proving the pre-indictment delay caused substantial actual prejudice to 
    his right to a fair trial.Â  Second, if the defendant shows actual prejudice, 
    the court must consider the prosecutionâ€™s reasons for the delay and balance 
    the justification for delay with any prejudice to the defendant.Â  If the court 
    finds the delay was an intentional device to gain a tactical advantage over 
    the accused, the court should dismiss the indictment. Id.; Howell 
    v. Barker, 904 F.2d 889 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 498 U.S. 1016, 
    111 S. Ct. 590, 112 L.Ed.2d 595 (1990); United States v. Automated Medical 
    Laboratories, Inc., 770 F.2d 399 (4th Cir. 1985).Â  When balancing 
    the prejudice and the justification, â€œ[t]he basic inquiry then becomes whether 
    the governmentâ€™s action in prosecuting after substantial delay violates â€˜fundamental 
    conceptions of justiceâ€™ or â€˜the communityâ€™s sense of fair play and decency.â€™â€Â  
    Howell, 904 F.2d at 895 (quoting United States v. Automated Medical 
    Laboratories, Inc., 770 F.2d 399, 404 (4th Cir.1985)).

Brazell, 325 S.C. at 72-73, 480 S.E.2d at 
  68-69.
Reliance on the Fourth Circuitâ€™s interpretation of the pre-indictment delay 
  test is significant in that it applies a less stringent standard as compared 
  to other federal circuits. Â See Jones v. Angelone, 94 F.3d 900, 
  905 (4th Cir. 1996) (recognizing that federal circuits, with the 
  exception of the Fourth Circuit and the Ninth Circuit, have held that â€œin order 
  to establish that a lengthy pre-indictment delay rises to the level of a due 
  process violation, a defendant must show not only actual substantial prejudice, 
  but also that â€˜the government intentionally delayed the indictment to gain an 
  unfair tactical advantage for other bad faith motivesâ€™â€ (quoting United States 
  v. Crooks, 766 F.2d 7, 11 (1st Cir.), cert. denied, 474 U.S. 996 
  (1985))).
Under the Fourth Circuitâ€™s standard, a defendant 
  who meets the initial burden of proving substantial actual prejudice does not 
  have to further prove improper prosecutorial motive as the cause for the delay.Â  
  Howell v. Barker, 904 F.2d 889, 894-95 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 
  498 U.S. 1016 (1990).Â  In rejecting the decisions from the majority of the federal 
  circuits, the Fourth Circuit reasoned as follows:

  Taking this position to its logical conclusion would mean that no matter 
    how egregious the prejudice to a defendant, and no matter how long the preindictment 
    delay, if a defendant cannot prove improper prosecutorial motive, then no 
    due process violation has occurred.Â  This conclusion, on its face, would violate 
    fundamental conceptions of justice, as well as the communityâ€™s sense of fair 
    play.Â  Moreover, this conclusion does not contemplate the difficulty defendants 
    either have encountered or will encounter in attempting to prove improper 
    prosecutorial motive.Â  

Howell, 904 F.2d at 895.
Despite the clear reliance on Fourth Circuit precedent in Brazell, the 
  State contends our supreme court did not adopt the more lenient standard for 
  pre-indictment delay.Â  Instead, â€œthe State submits that the burden is on the 
  defendant to show that the delay was intentional and to gain a tactical advantage.â€ 
  Â Â We disagree with this contention.
Although a trial court should dismiss an indictment 
  if the defendant shows improper prosecutorial motive for delaying indictment, 
  such a showing is not required for pre-indictment delay to violate due process.Â  
  Brazell, 325 S.C. at 72, 480 S.E.2d at 69.Â  While a finding of improper 
  prosecutorial motive ends the inquiry, the absence of such a showing does not 
  likewise terminate the analysis.Â  Instead, the proper course is to proceed to 
  the two-prong inquiry applied in the Fourth Circuit in the case of United 
  States v. Automated Medical Laboratories, Inc., 770 F.2d 399, 403-04 (4th 
  Cir. 1985), and adopted by our supreme court in Brazell.Â  Under this 
  test, the defendant first has the burden of proving the pre-indictment delay 
  caused substantial actual prejudice to his right to a fair trial.Â  Id.Â Â  
  Second, the court must then consider the Stateâ€™s reason for the delay and balance 
  the justification for delay with any prejudice to the defendant.Â  Id.
Here, the trial court erred as a matter of law in placing 
  the burden on Lee to prove substantial actual prejudice as well as the Stateâ€™s 
  improper motive for the delay.Â  Because the court required Lee to demonstrate 
  intentional delay by the State, the courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error 
  of law.Â  United States v. Lynch, No. 94-5350, 1995 WL 325670, at *2 (4th 
  Cir. June 1, 1995) (recognizing district courtâ€™s decision regarding pre-indictment 
  delay was a mixed question of law and fact and will only be reversed if clearly 
  erroneous) (citing United States v. Beszborn, 21 F.3d 62 (5th Cir. 1994), 
  cert. denied, Westmoreland v. United States, 513 U.S. 934 (1994)).Â  
  Without this additional burden, we find Lee established that the delay caused 
  substantial actual prejudice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In applying the first prong, â€œsubstantial 
  prejudiceâ€ requires a showing that the defendant â€œâ€˜was meaningfully impaired 
  in his ability to defend against the stateâ€™s charges to such an extent that 
  the disposition of the criminal proceeding was likely effected [sic].â€™â€Â  Brazell, 
  325 S.C. at 73, 480 S.E.2d at 69 (quoting Jones v. Angelone, 94 F.3d 
  900, 907 (4th Cir. 1996)).Â  â€œWhen the claimed prejudice is the unavailability 
  of a witness, courts require that the defendant identify the witness he would 
  have called; demonstrate, with specificity, the expected content of that witnessâ€™ 
  testimony; establish that he made serious attempts to locate the witness; and 
  finally, show that the information the witness would have provided was not available 
  from other sources.â€Â  Brazell, 325 S.C. at 73, 480 S.E.2d at 69.
We note Lee did more than merely rely on the length 
  of the delay to establish substantial actual prejudice.Â  As Leeâ€™s counsel pointed 
  out, the delay of twelve years presented a significant obstacle in preparing 
  an adequate defense and receiving a fair trial.Â  All the records from the family 
  court case have been destroyed.Â  No records contemporaneous with the alleged 
  offenses are available, particularly those explaining why the stepdaughters 
  were placed back into Leeâ€™s home after being removed.Â  Leeâ€™s efforts to acquire 
  the same information from other sources were likewise unavailing.Â  Leeâ€™s original 
  attorney could not be located, and the DSS investigator could recall no specifics 
  about the investigation.Â  Without this information, Leeâ€™s counsel could not 
  adequately cross-examine the victims and other family members regarding the 
  alleged incidents and the juvenile investigation that prompted DSS to become 
  involved.Â  Moreover, Leeâ€™s counsel was also prevented from refuting the delayed 
  disclosure evidence presented by the State through its expert witness. 
Because Lee established that he was actually and 
  substantially prejudiced, the inquiry turns to a consideration of the Stateâ€™s 
  reasons for the pre-indictment delay.Â  Under the second prong of the test, the 
  court must balance the Stateâ€™s justification for the delay against the prejudice 
  to the defendant.Â  Brazell, 325 S.C. at 72, 480 S.E.2d at 68-69.Â  In 
  this case, the State has offered no explanation for the delay in indicting Lee.Â  
  Given there is no valid justification, we find the Stateâ€™s prosecution of Lee 
  violated â€œâ€˜fundamental conceptions of justiceâ€™â€ and â€œâ€˜the communityâ€™s sense 
  of fair play and decency.â€™â€ Id. at 73, 480 S.E.2d at 69 (quoting Howell 
  v. Barker, 904 F.2d 889, 895 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 498 U.S. 1016 
  (1990)); see Howell, 904 F.2d at 895 (affirming district courtâ€™s 
  finding of unconstitutional pre-indictment delay where actual prejudice was 
  assumed and conceded and the State failed to offer valid justification for the 
  pre-indictment delay that prejudiced defendant).Â  Accordingly, Leeâ€™s convictions 
  involving his former stepdaughters are
VACATED.
HEARN, C.J. and STILWELL, J., concur.


 
   [1] Â  Pursuant to Anders 
    v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 
    S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), Leeâ€™s appellate counsel filed a brief along 
    with a petition to be relieved, stating her examination of the record indicated 
    the appeal was without merit.Â  Lee filed a separate pro se response.Â  
    Following our Anders review, this court ordered the parties to brief 
    the following issue:


  Whether the trial judge erred in declining to dismiss Leeâ€™s indictments 
    on the ground Leeâ€™s Fifth Amendment due process rights were violated as a 
    result of pre-indictment delay?


  This issue is now our sole appellate consideration.

 
   
    [2]  Although it is not entirely clear, it appears Leeâ€™s former stepdaughters 
    again came forward with their allegations after being informed of the more 
    recent 1999 incidents.

 
   [3]  Â Leeâ€™s counselâ€™s arguments 
    regarding Leeâ€™s right to a speedy trial were intertwined with her motion to 
    dismiss for pre-indictment delay; thus, we briefly address this issue.Â  Here, 
    Lee was arrested in March of 2001 and indicted and tried in May 2001.Â  Because 
    there was not a significant delay between the time Lee was arrested and the 
    time he was tried, there is no merit to his contention that he was denied 
    his right to a speedy trial.Â  Therefore, we concluded during our Anders 
    review that the judge did not err in denying the motion to dismiss on this 
    ground. See State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 74, 480 S.E.2d 64, 
    70 (1997) (The Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution 
    as well as Article 1, Section 14 of the South Carolina Constitution provide 
    that a criminal defendant is entitled to a speedy trial.); see also 
    United States v. Marion, 404 U.S. 307, 313-15 (1971) (discussing pre-indictment 
    delay in the context of the Sixth Amendment speedy trial provision; concluding 
    Sixth Amendment speedy trial provision does not provide defendant protection 
    until he or she is indicted).Â
